Strategy Description Doping introducing bandgap narrowing through interactions of cation states with valence or conduction bands, or creating intrabandgap levels; suppressing the formation of “killer defects” (enhancing ηabsorption and ηseparation) (Oxy)nitride and oxysulfide modifying the VB by incorporating N 2p or S 2p anions, leading to a narrowed bandgap (enhancing ηabsorption) Solid solution adjusting bandgaps and energy levels by varying the ratios of wide- and narrow-bandgap semiconductors (enhancing ηabsorption) Z-scheme system utilizing a two-step photoexcitation process with an HEP and an OEP, both with narrow bandgaps (enhancing ηabsorption and ηseparation) Flux treatment tailoring crystallinity and grain boundary structure to limit defect formation (enhancing ηseparation) Combination of different cocatalyst deposition methods enhancing cocatalyst dispersion and creating additional active sites (enhancing ηseparation and ηreaction) Co-deposition of HEC and OEC promoting charge separation by providing both reductive and oxidative active sites; spatially separating HEC and OEC through facet engineering (enhancing ηseparation and ηreaction) Two-component cocatalysts improving charge transport from the light absorber to the cocatalyst (enhancing ηseparation and ηreaction) Surface modification for HEC and photocatalyst effectively suppressing back reactions on the surface of HEC and light absorbers (enhancing ηreaction) Particle transfer method effectively facilitating charge separation and transfer between HEP and OEP in a Z-scheme configuration, or between the photocatalyst and the substrate in a photoelectrode (enhancing ηseparation) Available online 10 January 2025 Review Novel materials and techniques for photocatalytic water splitting developed by Professor Kazunari Domen Yaqiang Wu a b 1 Jianuo Li a 1 Wei-Kean Chong c 1 Zhenhua Pan d * Qian Wang a e * Dedicated to Prof. K. ABSTRACT Professor Kazunari Domen at the Shinshu University and the University of Tokyo has pioneered materials and techniques for solar-driven water splitting using photocatalysts, a promising technology for contributing to the construction of a sustainable and carbon-neutral society. In this paper, we summarize his groundbreaking contributions to photocatalytic water splitting and, more broadly, photocatalytic research. We highlight various novel functional photocatalytic materials, including oxides, (oxy)nitrides, and oxysulfides, along with innovative techniques such as cocatalyst engineering and Z-scheme system construction developed by the Domen Group. His team has also pioneered readily accessible and cost-effective photo(electro)chemical device fabrication methods, such as the particle-transfer method and thin-film-transfer method. Furthermore, their research has made significant contributions to understanding the (photo)catalytic mechanisms using advanced characterization techniques. Together with his research team, Professor Domen has set many milestones in the field of photocatalytic overall water splitting, notably demonstrating the first scalable and stable 100 m2 solar H2 production system using only water and sunlight. His work has revealed the potential for practical solar H2 production from water and sunlight, and highlighted the application of fundamental principles, combined with chemical and materials science tools, to design effective photocatalytic systems. Through this review, we focus on his research and the foundational design principles that can inspire the development of efficient photocatalytic systems for water splitting and solar fuel production. By building on his contributions, we anticipate a significant impact on addressing major global energy challenges. Graphical Abstract This Review highlights the innovative materials and versatile techniques pioneered by Professor Domen and his research team, which hold great promise for advancing photocatalytic processes and accelerating progress in solar fuel production. Keywords Photocatalysis Water splitting Solar H2 production Solar energy conversion Artificial photosynthesis 1 Introduction Harnessing energy directly from sunlight offers an ideal solution for meeting clean energy needs with minimal environmental impact. Solar energy is distributed and virtually inexhaustible. However, given the intermittency of sunlight, for solar energy to serve as a primary energy source, it must be stored and dispatched as electricity, heat or fuel on demand to end users. The key challenge in converting solar energy into electricity lies in significantly reducing the cost per watt of electricity produced. Over the past decade, substantial cost reductions in photovoltaic technology have driven a rapid increase in adoption, positioning photovoltaics as one of the most cost-effective future electricity generation options. As the industry evolves, it has become evident that area-related expenses such as those associated with encapsulation and installation are now a significant part of the total costs in photovoltaic power production, a trend likely to continue [1]. Enhancing energy conversion efficiency directly lowers these costs. However, without cost-effective energy storage solutions, solar electricity cannot serve as a primary energy source due to fluctuations in sunlight availability. While batteries could theoretically store this electricity, battery technologies are currently not affordable enough to meet long-term cost-per-watt goals across a solar device's 30-year lifespan [2]. Natural photosynthesis is relatively inefficient when considered on an annual average per unit area of sunlight received. For instance, switchgrass, one of the fastest-growing crops, stores energy in biomass at an average rate of only 1 W m–2 per year [3]. Biofuels derived from plants have the potential to contribute significantly to liquid fuel supplies for transportation, yet improving energy conversion and storage efficiency is crucial. This would help minimize land use as a limiting factor in harnessing solar energy and storing it in chemical bonds. A promising approach is to develop artificial photosynthetic systems with efficiencies surpassing those of plants or algae. In artificial photosynthesis, the initial steps involve converting sunlight into heat or electrical current. Similar to how the phosphate bond in ATP is a crucial energy unit in biological systems, the H–H bond in hydrogen (H2) holds promise as a key energy source for a carbon-neutral society. To unlock this potential, H2 must be extracted from its stable source, water. This involves utilizing solar energy to drive the thermodynamically uphill process of water splitting, thereby producing H2 and generating oxygen (O2) as a byproduct. This process is becoming increasingly vital since hydrogen not only provides a high-energy, carbon-free transportation fuel but also functions as an energy storage medium, helping to mitigate the variability of solar power generation [4]. Solar-driven water splitting can also be achieved using solar thermal energy to drive the reaction. For instance, a solar-to-hydrogen (STH) efficiency of 0.7% was reported with porous monolithic CeO2 in an advanced solar-cavity receiver reactor, utilizing two-step thermochemical reactions [5]. This process involves metal oxide-based solar thermal water-splitting cycles, where hydrogen is generated through sequential high-temperature reduction and water reoxidation of a metal oxide. Since only the reduction step is endothermic, the second reoxidation step can be performed at night or when needed. Additionally, these two-step thermochemical reactions, operating at more practical reduction temperatures (1200–1500 °C) compared to direct thermolysis (> 2700 °C), offer a more feasible approach [6]. However, these systems require solar concentrators to focus thermal energy and generate high temperatures above 1000 °C. To realize the theoretical maximum STH efficiency of 20%–40% [7], further optimization of operating conditions such as heat recovery, temperature, pressure, and solar irradiation concentration is needed. Using semiconductors to capture and store solar energy in simple chemical forms, H2, offers another approach for scalable grid solar energy storage and utilization technology. This approach begins by converting solar energy into electricity or wireless current to drive a redox reaction. Solar H2 production from water is typically carried out using three main system configurations: photovoltaic modules connected to discrete electrolyzers (PV-E), photoelectrochemical (PEC) cells, and photocatalysis (PC), as shown in Fig. 1 . An overview of these typical solar fuel systems including key technical attributes and challenges are listed in Table 1 . PV-E can be achieved by connecting commercial photovoltaic modules directly to electrolyzers and/or catalytic electrodes. PEC systems are attractive for water splitting because they enable the water splitting reaction to occur directly at the semiconductor surface, allowing for the easy creation of an electric field at the semiconductor/liquid junction. The separated light collection structure in PV-E (spatially separated PV device with electrocatalysts) and PEC (separated photocathode and photoanode for producing H2 and O2, respectively) offer convenience for the modulation and optimization of each component. Additionally, the successful research and development have enabled their STH efficiencies to reach over 19% [8,9]. However, rigorous economic analyses indicated that achieving STH efficiencies greater than 20% with current embodiments of PV-E and PEC devices was not sufficient to achieve H2 competitive with fossil-fuel-derived hydrogen at the production cost, primarily due to high costs associated with panel mounting materials and labor expense [4]. Photocatalytic H2 production from water can be realized using homogeneous systems that involve an organic sensitizer (e.g., dye) and molecular catalysts/enzymes in solution [10,11]. However, these multicomponent systems typically require sacrificial chemical reductants and a soluble redox mediator to transfer electrons from the light absorber to the catalyst. Additionally, the stability is a significant obstacle to the durability of their performance in aqueous solution and O2-rich atmosphere. An alternative approach involves using particles of inorganic semiconductors in conjunction with heterogeneous cocatalysts, which have been demonstrated to act as photocatalytic water-splitting systems. These systems are projected to be simpler and more cost-effective than the PV-E and PEC cells, as solar energy collection and conversion can be performed on a single particle. Fig. 2 illustrates a typical semiconductor particle with a hydrogen evolution cocatalyst (HEC) and an oxygen evolution cocatalyst (OEC) on its surface, which serves as a photocatalyst for overall water splitting. The overall transformation is a multielectron process driven by photocatalysts and light, comprising three key processes: (1) photon absorption, where photons with energy greater than the semiconductor bandgap excite electrons from the valence band (VB) to the conduction band (CB), generating electron (e–)/hole (h+) pairs; (2) separation of the photoexcited carriers into free carriers, followed by their migration to the active sites on the particle surface; and (3) initiation of redox reactions at the active sites, where the accumulated charges, with the aid of cocatalysts, drive the production of H2 and O2. The reactions involved in overall water splitting are summarized below: Hydrogen evolution reaction (HER): (1.1) 2H+ + 2e– → H2 (0 V vs. NHE at pH 0) Oxygen evolution reaction (OER): (1.2) H2O → 1/2O2 + 2e– + 2H+ (1.23 V vs. NHE at pH 0) (1.3) Overall reaction: H2O → H2 + 1/2O2 (ΔE = 1.23 V; ΔG = 237.2 kJ/mol at 298 K and 1 atm) Therefore, the overall solar energy conversion efficiency, STH, reflects the efficiencies of three processes and is expressed as follows: (1.4) STH = η absorption × η separation × η reaction Here: Photon absorption efficiency (η absorption): The fraction of electron-hole pairs generated by the incident photon flux. Carrier separation efficiency (η separation): The fraction of photogenerated charge carriers successfully separated and migrated to the solid-liquid interface. Redox reaction efficiency (η reaction): The efficiency with which the surface reactions involving the charge carriers occur at the solid-liquid interface. Because the HER and OER take place in close spatiotemporal proximity on individual photocatalyst particles, the need for supporting electrolytes, pH-buffer reagents, and vigorous circulation of the electrolyte solution to minimize solution resistance and concentration overpotentials in common PV-E and PEC systems can be avoided. This approach also eliminates the need for expensive membranes required to separate the anolyte and catholyte [12]. Therefore, the photocatalytic system is readily scalable at a relatively low cost without severe deterioration in its activity [12,13]. These merits of photocatalytic systems enable an estimated average cost of H2 production in the range of 1.6–3.5 $/kg, assuming STH efficiencies of 5%–10% and a system lifetime of 5 years [4]. These costs align with the target H2 price of 2.00–4.00 $/kg set by the United States Department of Energy. However, photocatalytic water splitting using particulate photocatalysts, especially with a single light absorber, encounters significant thermodynamic and kinetic barriers to chemical bond-making and -breaking processes, which involve multi-electron transfer coupled with proton transfer. A key research goal is to develop an efficient and stable photocatalytic system capable of cost-effective water splitting on a scale required to meet global energy demands, i.e., in the range of tens of terawatts. Professor Kazunari Domen is an eminent figure in the field of photocatalytic water splitting with a wealth of knowledge and expertise. He started the research on photocatalytic water splitting during his PhD study at The University of Tokyo, Japan in the 1980s. He has dedicated his career to advancing this technology for over 40 years, with his research interests encompassing a broad range including, but not limited to, material development, technology innovation, mechanism study, and practical application demonstration. Professor Domen has led his team to significant advancements in this field, aiming to design and develop effective photocatalytic water-splitting systems for practical solar hydrogen production. Here are some highlights of his research: (1) Exploration of novel photocatalytic materials, including light absorbers (such as visible-light-driven oxides, nitrides, oxynitrides, and oxysulfides) and cocatalysts (exemplified by core-shell structured cocatalysts). The Domen team reported various novel examples of achieving overall water splitting using a single visible-light-responsive photocatalyst, marking the beginning of a new era in artificial photosynthesis [16,17]. (2) Achievement of evolutionary and revolutionary performance improvements through various strategies, such as deposition and modulation of cocatalysts, surface modification, and construction of Z-scheme systems. These strategies have been widely used in various photocatalytic reactions, including water splitting and CO2 reduction [18,19]. (3) Utilization of advanced techniques and fruitful collaboration to enhance scientific understanding of (photo)catalytic processes, including transmission infrared (IR), infrared reflection absorption spectroscopy (IRAS), interfacial sum-frequency generation spectroscopy (SFG), and transient absorption spectroscopy (TAS). (4) Substantial progress in demonstrating the practical application viability of cost-effective photocatalytic water splitting technology. This involves designing and expanding photocatalyst sheets and panels aimed at large-scale H2 production. Although recently there has been a tremendous explosion of work in this field, the Domen team remains at the forefront of photocatalytic water splitting, consistently setting new records and benchmarks. In this Review, we use the Domen team's work as an example and adopt a historical approach to detail how they have developed effective photocatalytic materials and systems. The novel materials are enhanced through innovative strategies to address common challenges in photocatalysis—specifically, the limited solar energy harvesting ability, the rapid recombination of photogenerated carriers, and the sluggish kinetics of surface redox reactions—thereby improving η absorption, η separation and η reaction, and thus overall STH efficiency. These versatile and insightful materials and techniques pioneered by the Domen team hold promise for advancing various photocatalytic processes and accelerating progress in solar fuel production. More importantly, by reviewing the work of this esteemed scientist and exploring how the Domen team tailors photocatalytic materials and optimizes system performance, we aim to understand the fundamental principles governing these materials and the rationale behind future design and development. This overview highlights both past and current research, as well as the promising future perspectives made possible by the exciting developments of his team. 2 Innovative materials for photocatalytic water splitting 2.1 Oxide photocatalysts To drive photocatalytic water splitting, a photovoltage of > 1.23 V is required (Fig. 2). Therefore, at the early stage of this research field, wide-bandgap photocatalysts exemplified by oxides have been widely studied [20]. As Fujishima and Honda reported their pioneering PEC system using a TiO2 photoanode connected to a Pt cathode for water splitting under light irradiation with an external bias [21], it was expected that photocatalytic water splitting could be achieved by loading the counter electrode catalysts, Pt, on TiO2 particles. However, researchers encounter challenges with this approach for two main reasons with commonly used anatase-type TiO2 particles [22]: (1) Multiple deep trapped states were located above the VB of anatase TiO2, reducing the oxidative potential of photogenerated holes; (2) The Pt cocatalyst tends to promote undesired backward reactions, i.e., O2 reduction and the recombination of H2 and O2. The first issue is intrinsic to TiO2, promoting researchers to explore new materials as photocatalysts, such as SrTiO3, which was originally reported by M. S. Wrighton as a photoanode to split water without any external bias, and layer-structured oxides. 2.1.1 SrTiO3 Domen started his research of using SrTiO3 as a photocatalyst when he was a PhD student at Tamaru Group, the University of Tokyo. SrTiO3 is a typical perovskite oxide with Sr2+ coordinating to 12 oxygen atoms and Ti4+ coordinating to 6 oxygen atoms, wherein eight TiO6 octahedra with shared corners formed the three-dimensional framework of a cubic cell, the center of which is occupied by Sr2+ cation [23]. In 1980, using a glass-made closed-circulation reaction system–still widely adopted in the current photo(electro)catalytic research–he confirmed photocatalytic water vapor cleavage over NiO x -loaded SrTiO3 [24]. His further research revealed that the NiO x -loaded SrTiO3 in suspension could also decompose liquid water, and achieved photocatalytic water splitting (i.e. splitting water into H2 and O2 with a molar ratio of 2:1 without external bias) for the first time [25]. The success in splitting water using the above system was largely attributed to the unique structure of NiO x cocatalyst. Initially, Domen intended to construct an intimate p-n junction between NiO and SrTiO3 by first reducing Ni2+ ions to metallic Ni with H2 and subsequently fully oxidizing metallic Ni into a p-type NiO with O2. By constructing an intimate NiO/SrTiO3 junction, the charge separation in SrTiO3 was supposed to be significantly improved. However, experiments revealed that fully converting metallic Ni to NiO under high-temperature oxidation did not produce an active sample as expected. In contrast, partially oxidizing Ni to NiO was confirmed to be the key to activating the samples. Subsequent studies utilizing X-ray photoemission (XPS) and Extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) revealed that NiO x obtained through reduction and partial oxidation processes exhibited a core/shell structure. In this structure, the NiO shell was permeable to small molecules/ions such as H+ and H2, but not to O2, while the Ni core worked as an active site for HER [26,27]. Though the preparation of a NiO shell is not universal, and the Ni core is not as active as noble metals like Pt for catalyzing HER, the development of core/shell Ni/NiO shows a clear way to suppress the backward reactions during photocatalytic water splitting. This pioneering invention inspired the development of Cr2O3 and amorphous TiO2 (a-TiO2) shells, which are widely applied in current photocatalytic systems [28–32]. The details will be discussed in Section 3.1.3. In the early years, despite optimizing cocatalyst loading methods and SrTiO3 synthesis, the activity of SrTiO3 for photocatalytic water splitting remained quite low, as reflected by its quantum efficiency <1% [27,33–37]. Considering charge separation in the bulk was critical for the photocatalytic performance at this stage, Domen et al. [38] applied defect engineering to SrTiO3 by employing aliovalent-metal-ion doping. They discovered that the low-valent cation doping, i.e., p-type doping with Na+ into Sr2+ or Ga3+ into Ti4+, efficiently enhanced photocatalysis by introducing oxygen vacancies and reducing Ti3+ defects. In contrast, the high-valent doping, i.e., n-type doping with La3+ into Sr2+ or Ta5+ into Ti4+, suppressed photocatalytic water splitting. This doping engineering with metal ions was proved to improve the electronic structure of SrTiO3 without introducing mid-gap energy levels. By combining metal-ion doping with the recently developed facet engineering [39,40], Domen et al. [39–42] developed highly crystallized, faceted Al-doped SrTiO3 (SrTiO3:Al) through a reaction between SrTiO3 and Al2O3 in SrCl2 flux, resulting in modified morphology and enhanced photocatalytic activities, as shown in Fig. 3 . In such synthesis, the crystallinity and particle size of SrTiO3 increased following the SrCl2 flux treatment. The morphology changed from irregular shapes with particle sizes of hundred nanometers to truncated cubic shapes with particle sizes of 0.2–2 μm. When Al2O3 was intentionally added to SrCl2 flux (at a 1:100 molar ratio), the particles became nearly uniform, with their size reduced to a few hundred nanometers in diameter. TAS revealed that SrTiO3:Al contained energy states near the CB and VB, while eliminating the sub-band gap states observed in pristine SrTiO3 [43,44]. During the photocatalytic reaction, the photogenerated electrons were shallowly trapped by the extrinsic states near the CB, permitting the re-excitation to the high-energy CB for the subsequent transfer to the cocatalysts. Concurrently, the shallowly trapped photogenerated holes near the VB migrate to the adjacent cocatalysts to facilitate surface reactions. As a result, an apparent quantum efficiency (AQY) of SrTiO3:Al reached 30% at 360 nm, while this value was at the level of ~1% in the previous studies [25,26,35,45]. In subsequent years, the photocatalytic activity of SrTiO3:Al was further enhanced through optimized cocatalyst loading. For example, co-loading MoO x and Rh2–y Cr y O3 on SrTiO3:Al achieved an AQY of 56% at 365 nm [12,42]. Remarkably, when Cr2O3/Rh as HEC and CoOOH as OEC were selectively loaded on the reductive ({100}) and oxidative ({110}) facets of SrTiO3:Al, respectively, the AQY approached the theoretically maximum of 100% at 350–360 nm [46]. SrTiO3 has a wide bandgap of ~3.2 eV, which restricts its absorption to high-energy ultraviolet light, which constitutes only a small portion of the solar spectrum. Nonetheless, advances in SrTiO3 mark a groundbreaking approach to activating photocatalysts. Additionally, SrTiO3 serves as an ideal model for studying the mechanism of photocatalytic water splitting. 2.1.2 Layered structure oxides Metal oxides with a layered structure (Fig. 4(a) ) are another typical type of UV-responsive photocatalysts capable of splitting water. The layered structure benefits photocatalytic water splitting in several ways [47,48]: (1) The redox sites could be located within the space-confined interlayers, reducing the migration distance of charge carriers to the reaction sites; (2) As the reaction sites for H2 and O2 evolution can be spatially separated, the possibility of H2-O2 recombination is reduced, as shown in Fig. 4(b)); (3) Cocatalysts, such as Ni and Pt nanoclusters, can be intercalated into the interlayer space, which is negatively charged (Fig. 4(c)). The negative electric field facilitates the diffusion of H+ towards the cocatalyst for H2 evolution while inhibiting the diffusion of O2, thereby suppressing backward reactions. In 1986, Domen et al. [47] reported K4Nb6O17 as the first layered structure photocatalyst for H2 evolution using methanol as an electron donor. This material features two types of interlayers in the structure: one containing H2O molecules and K+ ions (interlayer I), and the other one containing only K+ ions without H2O molecules (interlayer II) in water vapor. A notable characteristic of K4Nb6O17 is that the K+ ions between the niobium oxide layers can be replaced with other cations, such as protons and various metal ions [51]. Domen et al. [52] discovered that the K+ exchanging with H+, Cr3+ or Fe3+ promoted the photocatalytic H2 evolution activity of K4Nb6O17 from an aqueous methanol solution while exchanging with Co2+, Ni2+ or Cu2+ had a negative effect. In particular, H+-exchanged K4Nb6O17 showed a H2 evolution activity with an AQY of 50% at 330 nm in a methanol aqueous solution. The effective separation of electrons and holes was likely due to the electrostatic gradient within the niobate sheet, caused by the differing locations of K+ and H+ ions between interlayers I and II [50]. Furthermore, K4Nb6O17 demonstrated the ability to perform photocatalytic water splitting even without the assistance of cocatalysts, although its activity was significantly lower, being 9 times less than that of the sample loaded with Ni metal nanoparticle cocatalyst [53]. It was found that the photocatalytic activity was sensitive to the loading amount of Ni, showing a downtrend in the range of 0.1 wt%–20 wt%, as only ultrafine Ni clusters smaller than 5 Å can be accommodated within interlayer I of K4Nb6O17 [38]. When the Ni loading exceeded 0.1 wt%, the Ni metal clusters formed from the reduction of Ni2+ ions became larger than the interlayer spacing, leading to the destruction of the layered structure. Inspired by the development of K4Nb6O17, the family of layered perovskite-type compounds with a formula of A′[A 2 B 3O10] (A′ = K, Rb, Cs; A = Ca, Pb; B = Nb, Ta, etc.) (Dion-Jacobson phase) and A′2[A 2 B 3O10] (A′ = K, Rb; A = La; B = Ti) (Ruddlesden-Popper phase) was also investigated for photocatalytic water splitting. The Dion-Jacobson phase did not hydrate in air, while the Ruddlesden-Popper phase did. After the H+ exchange reaction, both types of layered perovskites showed high photocatalytic activity for H2 evolution in the presence of sacrificial reagents such as methanol [54,55]. However, H+-exchanged forms of both layered perovskites could not achieve the overall water-splitting reaction. In contrast, K2La2Ti3O10 and Rb2La2Ti3O10, which contain alkaline metal cations in the interlayer and spontaneously hydrate in air and/or in an aqueous solution, achieved the overall water-splitting reaction after NiO/Ni cocatalyst loading. Notably, although the Domen team could not develop a Dion-Jacobson phase photocatalyst to split water, Ebina et al. [56] at the National Institute for Materials Science (Japan) succeeded in this by exfoliating KCa2Nb3O10. At the same time, Ruddlesden-Popper phase K2La2Ti3O10 and Rb2La2Ti3O10, consisting of negatively charged titanlanthanate perovskite layers and interlayer potassium ions, have been reported by Domen et al. [49,57,58] for photocatalytic overall water splitting in aqueous alkaline solution after loading NiO/Ni cocatalyst. Different from K4Nb6O17, K2La2Ti3O10 contained reaction sites for OER located in the interlayer space, and Ni particles functioned as the reaction sites for HER on the external surface probably due to the difference of the mobilities between photoexcited electrons and holes [57]. Though the layered structure photocatalysts with large bandgaps (~3.3 eV) are responsive to only UV, they can be applied for constructing Z-scheme systems for water splitting under visible light irradiation upon dye-sensitization [59,60]. For example, Abe et al. [59] reported that the dye (coumarin or carbazole)-sensitized, Pt-loaded K4Nb6O17 as the H2 evolution photocatalyst (HEP) combined with IrO2/Pt-loaded WO3 as the O2 evolution photocatalyst (OEP), constructing a Z-scheme system mediated by I3 −/I− redox for overall water splitting under visible-light irradiation (λ > 410 nm). In this system, Pt cocatalyst was confined in the interlayer of K4Nb6O17, allowing the H2 evolution at Pt sites while inhibiting the approaching of I3 − due to the electrostatic repulsion between I3 − and negatively charged (Nb6O17)4 − layers. Furthermore, Maeda et al. [60] reported the dye (Ru complex)-sensitized layered HCa2Nb3O10, modified with Al2O3 and poly(styrenesulfonate) layers, functioned as the HEP in a Z-scheme system in combination with PtO x /H-Cs-WO3 as OEP. In this system, backward electron transfer in two paths, i.e., the excited electrons in the CB of the HEP to surface adsorbed oxidized Ru complex, and to the oxidation product of I3 − in solution, were significantly suppressed by Al2O3 and poly(styrenesulfonate) modification, respectively, resulting in the enhancement of STH to 0.12%. 2.2 Visible-light-responsive photocatalysts Investigating oxide photocatalysts exemplified by SrTiO3 has verified the technical feasibility of photocatalytic water splitting without the need for sacrificial reagents. However, these oxide photocatalysts often compromise their light absorption capacity to achieve a high driving force necessary for redox reactions. Taking SrTiO3:Al as an example, despite advancements in the material design that have enabled a quantum efficiency of 100% at ~360 nm for water splitting, its limited light absorption in the UV region restricts the STH efficiency to less than 1%. To effectively harness the solar spectrum and make photocatalytic water splitting viable on a practical scale, it is crucial to develop visible-light-responsive photocatalysts, particularly those that can respond to wavelengths up to 600 nm [61]. In the early development of visible-light-responsive photocatalysts, cadmium chalcogens, and their solid solutions, for example, CdS with intrinsic narrow bandgaps gained significant attention [62,63]. However, these materials tend to favor photocorrosion over O2 evolution on the oxidation side, making reliable photocatalytic water splitting challenging. Another strategy for developing visible-light-driven photocatalysts involves doping oxide photocatalysts with metal ions (e.g., Cr3+, Rh3+) [64] and non-metal ions (e.g., N3−, S2−) [65]. In this approach, dopants induce visible-light absorption by creating discrete energy levels within the forbidden band of the host photocatalysts. However, this method often results in a relatively slow migration of photogenerated charge carriers. Moreover, dopants can disrupt the charge balance and crystal structure of the host materials, forming defects that serve as charge recombination centers. Due to these disadvantages, most visible-light-responsive photocatalysts produced by doping have been effective only for H2 and/or O2 evolution in the presence of sacrificial reagents. Only a few exceptions, such as Sb and Rh co-doped SrTiO3 as well as Ir and La co-doped KTaO3, have been reported to achieve photocatalytic water splitting without sacrificial reagents [66,67]. Most oxide photocatalysts have a CB potential just above the H2 evolution potential (E(H+/H2), Fig. 2), but their VB potentials are far below the O2 evolution potential (E(O2/H2O)), leading to a large bandgap. With this in mind, Domen et al. attempted to develop new visible-light-responsive photocatalysts by tuning the VB position while maintaining the CB position. They noticed that the potentials of N 2p and S 3p orbitals are more negative than that of O 2p orbitals and certain transition metal-based oxynitride materials had been reported as non-toxic pigments [68]. Based on this observation, Domen et al. proposed the development of (oxy)nitride and oxysulfide photocatalysts, which were supposedly ideal candidates for photocatalytic water splitting under visible light. However, the introduction of N 2p and S 3p orbitals into the VB can cause stability issues for photocatalysts. Specifically, water oxidation for O2 evolution may compete with the photocorrosion of N3− or S2− ions. The photocorrosion can be suppressed by loading cocatalysts, such as CoO x , or applying a protective layer, like amorphous TiO2, as discussed in the following context. Strategies for protecting (oxy)nitrides and oxysulfides during photocatalytic water splitting have also been detailed in our previous review paper [69]. The band diagrams of representative photocatalysts developed by the Domen team and their typical photocatalytic activity for one-step overall water splitting to produce both H2 and O2 are summarized in Fig. 5 and Table 2 , respectively. 2.2.1 TaON0020and Ta3N5 In 2002, Domen and his team [97] began exploring visible-light-responsive photocatalysts, focusing on tantalum-based (oxy)nitrides. Their initial breakthrough came with the development of the TaON photocatalyst, which they reported could drive OER using Ag+ as an electron acceptor under visible light irradiation (420 < λ < 500 nm). The TaON material has a baddeleyite-type structure, with the occupational ordering of anions in alternating layers of NTa4 and OTa3 along the [100] direction, as shown in Fig. 6(a) . In this structure, each NTa4 tetrahedron is connected to four corner-shared NTa4, four edge-shared NTa4, two corner-shared OTa3, and one edge-shared OTa3. Conversely, each OTa3 triangle is linked with twelve corner-shared NTa4, one edge-shared NTa4, three corner-shared OTa3, and one edge-shared OTa3 [98]. The TaON particles were synthesized by annealing Ta2O5 in an NH3 flow. This process replaced some of the O2− ions in Ta2O5 with N3−, resulting in a VB composed mainly of N 2p with a minor contribution from O 2p orbitals and thus a reduced bandgap of 2.5 eV (λ < 500 nm), compared to the larger bandgap of Ta2O5 (3.9 eV) (Fig. 6(b)). Later that same year, the Domen team [99] introduced tantalum nitride, Ta3N5, which exhibited a higher degree of nitridation compared to TaON and was capable of both H2 and O2 evolution in the presence of sacrificial reagents. Ta3N5 comprises edge-shared TaN6 octahedral units, where each tantalum atom is coordinated with six nitrogen atoms, and the nitrogen atoms are three- or four-fold coordination. Since the VB of Ta3N5 consisted of only N 2p orbitals, its bandgap further decreased to 2.1 eV (λ < 600 nm). To guide the development of (oxy)nitrides, Domen et al. [100] conducted detailed studies of the electronic structures of Ta2O5, TaON, and Ta3N5 using ultraviolet photoelectron spectroscopy (UPS) and electrochemical analyses. They found that while the conduction band minimum (CBM) positions of Ta2O5, TaON, and Ta3N5 were relatively similar, there was a significant variation in their valence band maximum (VBM) positions. The potential energy differences with respect to O2/H2O decreased in the order of Ta2O5 < TaON < Ta3N5. The bandgap energies were determined to be 3.9, 2.4, and 2.1 eV, respectively, as shown in Fig. 6(b). These experimental findings aligned with density functional theory (DFT) calculations and neutron and synchrotron diffraction analyses, which revealed that the CBs of these materials primarily consisted of Ta 5d orbitals, while their VBs were mainly composed of O 2p, O 2p + N 2p, and N 2p orbitals for Ta2O5, TaON and Ta3N5, respectively [98]. These electronic analyses confirmed that TaON and Ta3N5, with their visible light absorption ability, are thermodynamically suitable for photocatalytic water splitting. In the following years, various optimizations in synthesis methods and modifications, including surface passivation, defect engineering, and elemental doping, were applied to enhance the photocatalytic performance of Ta3N5 and TaON for HER or/and OER [101,102]. Particularly, surface modification with thermally stable ZrO2 nanoparticles (10–30 nm) as the protectors effectively inhibited the formation of Ta4+ (or Ta3+) which typically results from the reduction of Ta5+ during nitridation. Such surface modification effectively reduced defect density in TaON, thereby more than doubling its activity for HER [103]. Subsequent studies revealed that doping Zr4+ into TaON or Ta3N5 produced similar benefits as ZrO2 surface modification. Furthermore, co-doping with Zr and Mg reduced defect density while simultaneously modulating the surface properties [104,105], leading to an increase in electron concentration and extended the lifetimes of photogenerated carriers. When Pt cocatalyst was loaded on Zr and Mg co-doped Ta3N5, the H2 evolution rate was increased 45-fold compared to pristine Ta3N5 [105]. At this stage of research, as improvements were made to TaON and Ta3N5 for sacrificial HER or OER, these materials were used to construct Z-scheme systems for overall water splitting. For example, a Z-scheme system combing ZrO2-modified TaON (HEP), WO3 (OEP), and I−/IO3 − (redox mediator) achieved a recorded AQY of 6.3% at 420 nm at that time. The remarkable performance of TaON for HER attracted further attention from other researcher groups, leading to subsequent studies that increased the AQY at 420 nm to more than 10% [106–108]. TaON is capable of evolving both H2 and O2 in the presence of electron donor and acceptor, respectively, making them promising candidates for non-sacrificial water splitting once charge-separation efficiency and surface catalysis are improved. In 2013, Domen et al. [93] reported the first instance of using ZrO2-modified TaON for photocatalytic water splitting, where core/shell-structured RuO x /Cr2O3 nanoparticles and colloidal IrO2 were co-loaded to facilitate HER and OER, respectively. These cocatalysts were effective in extracting electrons and holes from TaON, promoting surface reactions. However, the random loading of these cocatalysts on TaON may cause charge recombination, resulting in low water splitting activity, with an AQY of < 0.1% at 420 nm. Subsequent improvements were made by reducing the particle size of TaON and lowering its defect densities. This was achieved by using amorphous Ta2O5·3.3 H2O nanoparticles as a new precursor for synthesis, alongside Zr doping and optimized nitridation conditions. As a result, the water-splitting activity was enhanced by an order of magnitude [91]. TaON was among the first oxynitrides studied due to its relatively large bandgap, which provides a strong driving force for charge separation. Consequently, TaON exhibits the highest H2 and O2 evolution activities among oxynitrides. However, its wide bandgap limits its ability to absorb sunlight with wavelengths shorter than 500 nm, resulting in a theoretical maximum STH efficiency of ~8%. Additionally, TaON is a transitional phase between Ta2O5 and Ta3N5, often leading to impurity formation during synthesis. These limitations have shifted subsequent research towards Ta3N5, which offers a narrower bandgap and simpler synthesis methods. For Ta3N5, the long-term nitridation process often leads to aggregated polycrystalline particles [109], which contain numerous grain boundaries and defects that act as recombination and trapping centers for photogenerated electrons and holes. Consequently, despite the activity of Ta3N5 for sacrificial H2 and O2 evolution, its water-splitting activity remained negligible [110–112]. To address these challenges, Domen et al. [90] developed a new approach to preparing Ta3N5. This method involved the in situ growth of Ta3N5 nanorods on a lattice-matched cubic KTaO3 template. During nitridation, K+ in the edges of cubic KTaO3 slowly evaporated and the remaining TaO x was rapidly converted to single-crystalline Ta3N5 nanorods without grain boundaries, as shown in Fig. 6(c). By shortening the nitridation time, the Ta3N5 nanorods avoided prolonged exposure to the highly reductive NH3 atmosphere, thereby reducing the formation of defects and the presence of Ta4+ and Ta3+ species. These single-crystal Ta3N5 nanorods were active for photocatalytic water splitting (Fig. 6(d)), achieving an AQY of 2.2% at 320 nm (± 25 nm). 2.2.2 d0-metal-based oxynitrides Perovskite oxides with an ABO3 structure provide an ideal template for developing oxynitrides because the valence variation resulting from substituting O2− with N3− can be balanced by adjusting the metal valences at the A and B sites. With this train of thought, Domen et al. [113] developed a series of perovskite-type oxynitrides with structures of ABO2N or ABON2, incorporating elements such as La3+, Ca2+, Sr2+ and Ba2+ at the A site, and Ti4+, Nb5+ and Ta5+ at the B site. These photocatalysts, including LaTiO2N, BaTiO2N, BaTaO2N, CaNbO2N and LaMg1/3Ta2/3O2N, have been confirmed to be responsive to visible light and thermodynamically suitable for water splitting. Domen and his team first reported the LaTiO2N for photocatalytic HER and OER in the presence of sacrificial reagents under visible-light irradiation (420 < λ < 600 nm) [114]. As shown in Fig. 7 , the LaTiO2N consists of TiO x N y octahedral (x + y = 6) frameworks with La3+ located in the center space, surrounded by eight TiO x N y octahedra. The band structure of LaTiO2N aligns with the characteristics of transition metal-based oxynitride materials discussed earlier, where the VB is composed primarily of N 2p orbitals and a minority of O 2p orbitals, while the CB consists of empty Ti 3d orbitals [61]. This structure results in a narrow bandgap, corresponding to a light absorption edge wavelength of ~600 nm [115]. Despite its advanced structure, LaTiO2N showed minimal activity for HER, probably because its CB composed of Ti 3d orbitals is only slightly above E(H+/H2) [114]. Conversely, LaTiO2N has proven to be one of the most active oxynitrides for OER. By nitridating mesoporous and microporous single-crystalline La2Ti2O7, which was obtained through a flux method, and being loaded with CoO x by post-nitridation, LaTiO2N stably evolved O2 from Ag+ aqueous solution with an AQY of 27.1 ± 2.6% at 440 nm [116]. Leveraging its remarkable OER performance, LaTiO2N was incorporated into a photocatalyst sheet for Z-scheme overall water splitting [117]. The activities of LaTiO2N for both HER and OER were further enhanced by removing the disordered surface layer using aqua regia [118]. This etching treatment eliminated surface defects in LaTiO2N, facilitating intimate contact with cocatalysts. However, this photocatalyst has not yet achieved water splitting, probably due to the unbalanced activities for H2 and O2 evolution. In comparison with LaTiO2N, ATaO2N (A = Ca, Sr, Ba) oxynitrides possess more negative CBs consisting of Ta 5d orbitals, which contribute to their decent activities for HER from sacrificial methanol aqueous solutions. Among these, CaTaO2N and BaTaO2N have demonstrated stable water-splitting capabilities in Z-scheme systems when combined with WO3 as an OEP and I−/IO3 − as a shuttle redox [119,120]. BaTaO2N, in particular, has garnered significant attention in subsequent studies due to its long light absorption edge of ~660 nm and relatively high stability. For instance, the forming of BaTaO2N-BaZrO3 solid solution was shown to enhance charge separation and reduce defect density, leading to a 9-fold increase in HER when using an electron donor [121]. Notably, even without forming a solid solution, a well-defined BaTaO2N photocatalyst can be prepared by adding BaCO3 into the precursors and using RbCl as a flux agent (Fig. 8 ). This synthesis method effectively suppressed the formation of impurities such as the Ta3N5 phase, and reduced defects like Ta4+ species and anion vacancies. The obtained BaTaO2N consisted of single-crystalline particles with exposed {100} and {110} facets, which facilitated efficient spatial charge separation [122]. When Pt was loaded as an HEC using a stepwise impregnation-photodeposition method, BaTaO2N evolved H2 from a methanol aqueous solution with an AQY of 6.8% at 420 nm. Additionally, in a Z-scheme water-splitting system (Pt/BaTaO2N|IO3 −/I−|PtO x /WO3), an STH of 0.24% was achieved [123]. While using flux-assisted nitridation is an effective approach for obtaining faceted and single-crystalline particles, this process typically results in particles with micrometers-scale sizes, which increases the migration distance of charge carriers to the surface for redox reactions. To address this challenge, Domen and his team optimized the precursor recipe, successfully reducing the particle size while maintaining the high crystallinity of perovskite-type photocatalysts [124]. By thermally nitriding a mixture of tantalum disulfide, metal hydroxides (A(OH)2), and molten-salt fluxes (e.g., SrCl2), they synthesized ATaO2N (A = Sr, Ca, Ba) single-nanocrystalline particles with sizes in the tens of nanometers. These particles exhibited excellent crystallinity and a tunable long-wavelength light response. Taking SrTaO2N as an example, after loading a Cr2O3/Ir-Pt cocatalyst to promote both reduction and oxidation reactions, the photocatalytic HER activity increased by two orders of magnitude. Furthermore, Z-scheme water splitting (Cr2O3/Ir-Pt/SrTaO2N|[Fe(CN)6]3−/ [Fe(CN)6]4−|Ir-CoFeO x /BiVO4) was first realized using this material, with an STH of 0.15% [124]. In addition to their use in sacrificial H2/O2 evolution and Z-scheme water splitting, ATaO2N oxynitrides have also been explored for one-step photoexcitation water splitting. The first successful example was a solid solution perovskite-type material, LaMg x Ta1−x O1+3x N2−3x (x ≥ 1/3), in which Ta5+ ions were stabilized by Mg2+ on the same site [85]. This material represents the first photocatalyst in the 600-nm class capable of one-step photoexcitation water splitting. To mitigate photocorrosion, LaMg x Ta1−x O1+3x N2−3x required protection with an amorphous TiO2 (a-TiO2) layer. The absence of an OEC in this system likely contributed to the limited AQY of 0.18% at 440 nm [85–87]. Similar strategies for cocatalyst loading and surface coating were applied to CaTaO2N [72]. Although one-step photoexcitation water splitting was also realized with this material, its effectiveness was constrained by its relatively short light-absorption edge wavelength of ~510 nm [72,73]. The development of LaMg x Ta1−x O1+3x N2−3x (x ≥ 1/3) demonstrates the potential of doping ATaO2N oxynitrides with aliovalent cations at the Ta sites to enhance their photocatalytic performance. By combining Mg doping with flux-assisted nitridation using RbCl, as mentioned in the previous paragraph, single-crystal Mg-doped BaTaO2N (BaTaO2N:Mg) particles were obtained, exhibiting increased charge densities, prolonged carrier lifetimes, and improved surface properties. With the loading of Rh/Cr2O3 and IrO2 cocatalysts, BaTaO2N:Mg successfully achieved one-step photoexcitation water splitting under visible light irradiation (λ > 420 nm), though the STH remained low at 4 × 10−4% [70]. Additionally, the use of amorphous Ta2O5·3H2O as a precursor, known for its advantages in activating TaON, was extended to synthesize BaTaO2N in combination with BaCO3. This recipe reduced the nitridation time to obtain crystallized BaTaO2N, thereby reducing the defect density. Modified with Rh (or Ru), Cr2O3, and IrO2 cocatalysts, this obtained BaTaO2N was capable of one-step photoexcitation water splitting, achieving an AQY and STH of 0.1% (420 nm) and 5 × 10–4%, respectively [71]. In light of these advancements, the synthesis of SrTaO2N, previously thought to be unstable, was revisited. Single-crystallized SrTaO2N was successfully obtained by nitriding SrCl2 and Ta2O5 with a NaOH additive. This method suppressed defect formation, allowing SrTaO2N to be active for one-step photoexcitation water splitting [88]. In comparison to ATaO2N oxynitrides, their niobium analogues, ANbO2N, exhibit broader light absorption spectra, with edge wavelengths of 600–750 nm [125,126]. Among these, CaNbO2N has demonstrated photocatalytic activity for both H2 and O2 evolution in aqueous solutions when using electron donors and acceptors, respectively. BaNbO2N, despite the longest light-adsorption-edge wavelength of ~740 nm, initially showed no activity for H2 or O2 production. However, upon loading Pt and CoO x cocatalysts, BaNbO2N became effective for sacrificial H2 and O2 evolution, respectively. In addition, adding BaCO3 into the Ba5Nb4O15 precursor improved the crystallinity and uniformity of BaNbO2N [127]. 2.2.3 d10-metal-based (oxy)nitrides The previous section discussed oxynitride photocatalysts based on transition metals with a d 0 electronic configuration. In these materials, the structural distortion of octahedral M(O/N)6, where M is the core transition metal ion, significantly impacts electronic delocalization and photocatalytic activity. Metals with an occupied d orbital, i.e., d 10 configuration, exhibit similar behavior to the d 0 configuration from a quantum chemistry perspective [128]. However, there are distinct differences in their band structures. For a d 0-type photocatalyst, the CB typically consists solely of d orbitals of the transition metal (e.g., Ta 4d for Ta3N5). In contrast, d 10-type photocatalysts often feature CB made up of sp orbitals from the metal (e.g., Ga 4s4p for GaN). The broad sp orbitals cause significant dispersion of the CB in d 10-type photocatalyst, which possibly provokes high mobility of photogenerated electrons. Consequently, the d 10-based materials offer unique advantages and potential for photocatalysis [128]. Domen et al. [81] began their investigation by exploring typical d 10-metal nitrides, such as GaN and Ge3N4 as photocatalysts. In 2005, his group reported the use of RuO2-loaded β-Ge3N4 as a photocatalyst for overall water splitting, producing both H2 and O2. This achievement makes the first successful demonstration of photocatalytic overall water splitting with a non-oxide material, highlighting the potential of this new class of photocatalysts [81,82,129]. Additionally, (Zn2+ or Mg2+)-doped GaN, when loaded with RuO2, was also found to be active for overall water splitting [75]. Notably, only GaN doped with divalent metal ions was active for overall water splitting, while doping with tetravalent metal ions (e.g., Si4+, Ge4+) did not yield similar results. This suggests that the p-type properties of GaN, which influence the concentration and mobility of holes, played a decisive role in its photocatalytic activity. Following these developments, Domen et al. [130] also achieved overall water splitting using undoped GaN microcrystals modified with Rh2–y Cr y O3 as a HEC, exhibiting an AQY of ca. 0.7% under 320 nm monochromatic light, thanks to the high crystallinity of the as-prepared GaN and the careful selection of cocatalysts [131]. Though β-Ge3N4 and GaN, after various modifications, were developed for water splitting, the large bandgaps (> 3 eV) limited their activity to UV irradiation. In 2005, Domen et al. [16,133] discovered that the solid solution of GaN and ZnO, denoted as (Ga1−x Zn x )(N1−x O x ), exhibited visible-light responsiveness and was active for overall water splitting when loaded with RuO2, despite both GaN and ZnO being UV-responsive on their own [135,136]. The wurtzite structure and similar lattice parameters of GaN and ZnO enabled the formation of this solid solution, with the X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns showing shifts to lower angles (Fig. 9(a) ) and the light absorption edge shifting from 440 to 500 nm with varying x values (from 0.05 to 0.42) (Fig. 9(b)) [61,137,138]. Initially, the bandgap narrowing was ascribed to p-d repulsion between Zn 3d and N 2p electrons in the upper part of the VB dominated by GaN [16,133]. More detailed investigations using photoluminescence spectroscopy and DFT calculations revealed that Zn atoms introduced acceptor levels just above the VB, while O atoms contributed donor levels just below the VB. This provides abundant electrons that could occupy the Zn-acceptor levels, resulting in visible-light absorption of this solid solution due to the electron transition from the Zn acceptor levels to the CB consisting of Ga 4s and 4p orbitals (Fig. 9(c)) [139]. (Ga1−x Zn x )(N1−x O x ) loaded with Rh2−y Cr y O3 nanoparticles proved to be a stable photocatalyst for overall water splitting under visible light [17], probably because the holes were accumulated on Zn acceptor level rather than N 2p orbitals. The highest photocatalytic activity was obtained when x was 0.12 and the nitridation time lasted for 15 h, with an AQY of ~6% at 420−440 nm (Fig. 9(d)) [134]. Increasing ZnO concentration in the solid solution expanded the light absorption spectrum but significantly reduced the photocatalytic activity [76]. The solid solution (Zn1+x Ge)(N2O x ) of ZnGeN2 and ZnO, synthesized by the nitridation of ZnO and GeO2, is another stable photocatalyst for overall water splitting under visible light (λ < 500 nm) [94,95,140]. This material features a wurtzite structure with the space group P63 mc, where oxygen substitutes for nitrogen in the crystal lattice. These materials exhibit visible light absorption capabilities, with bandgaps ranging from 2.5 to 2.7 eV, which depend on the composition and preparation conditions. These values were notably smaller than those of ZnGeN2 (~3.3 eV) and ZnO (~3.2 eV). The reduction in bandgap is attributed to the large VB dispersion and elevation of the VBM, which originated from the energy differences between O 2p and N 2p orbitals, as well as p-d repulsion between Zn 3d and N 2p-O 2p electrons in the upper VB. Upon loading with RuO2, (Zn1+x Ge)(N2O x ) was active for overall water splitting under visible light (λ < 500 nm). The activity was further improved through composition optimization and modification with Rh2−y Cr y O3, resulting in Rh2−y Cr y O3/(Zn1.44Ge)(N2.08O0.38) with an AQY of ~0.2% at 420 nm [94]. The two solid solutions, (Ga1−x Zn x )(N1−x O x ) and (Zn1+x Ge)(N2O x ), were visible-light responsive and active for overall water splitting; however, their light-absorption-edge were limited to wavelengths < 500 nm. To broaden the light-absorption spectrum to ~600 nm, Domen et al. [141] developed a Ga-Zn-In-O-N compound by incorporating InN (~1 eV) into (Ga1−x Zn x )(N1−x O x ). Although the as-prepared Ga-Zn-In-O-N compound exhibited a wurtzite structure, it was classified as a mixed nitride rather than a solid solution. The complete nitridation of the precursor mixture (GaN, ZnO, and InN) was challenging due to the thermal instability of InN at high temperatures and insufficient reactivity at low temperatures [142]. As a result, the Ga-Zn-In-O-N nitride, when loaded with Rh and CoO x as cocatalysts, was capable of producing H2 and O2 from water in the presence of sacrificial reagents but remained inactive for overall water splitting. 2.2.4 Oxysulfides Pyrochlore-structure A 2Ti2O7 (A = Y, Ln (Pr, Nd, Sm, Gd, Tb, Dy, Ho and Er)) semiconductors have been explored for photocatalytic water splitting under UV irradiation [74,143]. By using A2Ti2O7 materials as a template and substituting two O2− ions with two S2− ions, Domen et al. [61] developed a series of visible-light-harvesting titanium-based oxysulfides (A2Ti2O5S2). Unlike typical metal-chalcogenide photocatalysts like CdS, A2Ti2O5S2 features a VB composed of S 3p and O 2p orbitals. This composition not only provides visible light absorption ability but also contributes to better resistance against photocorrosion, with the ability to oxidize water to O2. In 2002, Sm2Ti2S2O5 was reported for its light response up to 600−650 nm and its photocatalytic activity for HER and OER from sacrificial solutions [144]. This material belongs to the I4/mmm crystallographic group and features a Ruddlesden-Popper-type layered perovskite structure, in which the layers are composed of S-(TiO2)-O-(TiO2)-S double octahedra (Fig. 10(a) ). DFT calculations indicated that the VB is made up of hybridized O 2p and S 3p orbitals as well as localized Sm 4f orbitals, while the CB consists of Ti 3d orbitals and Sm 4f orbitals (Fig. 10(b)) [144,145]. Subsequent studies focused on optimizing cocatalyst loading, surface treatment, and synthetic conditions to adjust the crystal morphology and reduce defect density. For example, CoO x deposition, converted from previously sulfurized CoS x through calcination in air, reduced defect site formation and improved charge separation for OER [146]. Ag2S nanoparticles were demonstrated to dramatically boost photo-oxidation reaction by forming a heterojunction with Sm2Ti2S2O5 [147,148]. Mg2+ doping into Ti4+ sites inhibited the formation of Ti3+ defects and improved HER activity [149]. Morphology control, crystallinity improvement, and surface defects removal were achieved by flux-assisted synthesis and post-treatment etching process, leading to improved photocatalytic performance [150,151]. After optimization, Sm2Ti2S2O5 emerged as one of the most active photocatalysts for H2 evolution and was used in Z-scheme water splitting as an HEP, in combination with an OEP such as WO3 or BiVO4 [150,151]. For instance, a Z-scheme system consisting of Cr2O3/Pt/IrO2/Sm2Ti2O5S2 as HEP, CoO x /BiVO4 as OEP, and reduced graphene oxide as the solid-state electron mediator achieved stable water splitting for over 100 hours with an STH of 0.22% [152]. Along with Sm2Ti2O5S2, other isologues in the Ln2Ti2O5S2 series (Ln = Pr, Nd, Gd, Tb, Dy, Ho, and Er) were also investigated for photocatalysis [153]. The photocatalytic performance of these materials depends largely on their band structure and defect density, such as sulfur vacancies and reduced Ti3+ species. Among them, Gd2Ti2O5S2 exhibited the highest photocatalytic activities for both HER and OER in sacrificial solutions. Initially, the AQY was only about 0.1% in the visible light region. Subsequent improvements, including flux-assisted synthesis and post-etching process, yielded plate-like, single-crystal Gd2Ti2O5S2 particles with well-ordered surfaces. Additionally, ultrafine Pt-IrO x composite particles were deposited on Gd2Ti2O5S2 via microwave heating, ensuring intimate contact. This enhanced photocatalyst showed an impressive AQY of 30% at 420 nm for H2 production from aqueous methanol solution [152,154]. In 2019, Domen et al. [92] achieved one-step photoexcitation water splitting with Y2Ti2O5S2, a photocatalyst notable for its extended light-absorption-edge wavelength, which was the longest among photocatalysts capable of water splitting at that time. The material was synthesized via a solid-state reaction under a sulfur-vapor atmosphere in a sealed quartz tube. As illustrated in Fig. 11 , the prolonged reaction (~100 h) resulted in large particles (~10 µm) mainly composed of secondary particles (~1–2 µm). Y2Ti2O5S2 exhibits a narrow bandgap of 1.9 eV and a broad light absorption range of up to 650 nm. As the band edge of Y2Ti2O5S2 was not pinned by hydroxyl radical, its CB and VB potentials relative to E(H+/H2) and E(O2/H2O) were independent of the pH of the reactant solution [144], making it suitable for both HER and OER at pH 9. After loading Cr2O3/Rh and IrO2 to promote H2 and O2 evolution, respectively, Y2Ti2O5S2 was capable of driving one-step photoexcited water splitting. Though the STH was still low (~0.007%), significantly below the theoretical maximum value of ~20%, Y2Ti2O5S2 stands out as a cost-effective photocatalyst due to the absence of expensive elements. To improve the synthesis of Y2Ti2O5S2, the defect states and phase formation mechanism were studied in detail [155]. It was found that Y2Ti2O5S2 was not directly formed from starting precursors but via intermediated phases such as Y2Ti2O7, Y2O2S, and TiS2 during the synthesis. The stepwise phase generation might be responsible for the formation of grain boundaries and secondary particles. Additionally, increasing the heating rate tended to reduce the particle size and suppress impurity formation. Based on this study, flux-assisted synthesis was employed to refine the morphology and crystallinity of Y2Ti2O5S2. Using a MgCl2-CaCl2 mixture as flux produced 2D sheet-structured Y2Ti2O5S2 with radial sizes of several micrometers and thicknesses of a few nanometers [156]. However, the incorporation of Mg2+ ions during the synthesis led to planar defects composed of S-Mg-S layers, which acted as the charge recombination centers. Eliminating the planar defects by using only CaCl2 as flux resulted in single-crystalline Y2Ti2O5S2 nanosheets with dimensions of 3−6 µm in-plane and thicknesses of ~0.1 µm [157]. More importantly, these nanosheets exposed {001} and {101} facets in the plane and edge positions, respectively. The structure facilitated anisotropic charge migration and the facet-selective photodeposition of cocatalysts. With these improvements, Y2Ti2O5S2 achieved an AQY of 18.2% at 420 nm for photocatalytic HER in the aqueous solution containing Na2S/Na2SO3 as the hole scavengers. La5Ti2 MS5O7 (M = Cu, Ag) is another class of oxysulfides that contain only fragments of layers in structure rather than complete layered perovskite. Both La5Ti2CuS5O7 and La5Ti2AgS5O7 are visible-light responsive, with a bandgap of 1.90 and 2.25 eV, respectively [158]. DFT calculations revealed that their CBs are composed of Ti 3d orbitals, while the compositions of VBs differ: La5Ti2CuS5O7 features hybrid Cu 3d and S 3p orbitals, whereas La5Ti2AgS5O7 has only S 3p orbitals [159]. Similar to A2Ti2O5S2-type oxysulfides, La5Ti2AgS5O7 is a n-type semiconductor. In contrast, La5Ti2CuS5O7 exhibits weak p-type behavior due to the presence of Cu energy states acting as acceptor levels above the VB. Interestingly, La5Ti2MS5O7 particles exhibit a rod-like structure, with the CB and VB spatially localized along one-dimensional chains made of Ti(O,S)6 octahedra and MS2 tetrahedra, respectively [159]. These one-dimensional chains are aligned along the long axis of each rod-like particle, promoting one-dimensional charge migration in the same direction [160]. Due to the similar ionic sizes of Ag+ and Cu+, La5Ti2MS5O7 can form a solid solution, La5Ti2Cu x Ag1–x S5O7 (x = 0–1), with a bandgap ranging from 2.25 to 1.65 eV. The most extensively investigated solid solution, La5Ti2Cu0.9Ag0.1S5O7, has a bandgap of 1.75 eV and properties similar to La5Ti2CuS5O7. As the CBs of La5Ti2MS5O7 and its solid solution are positioned above E(H+/H2), and their VBs are just below E(O2/H2O), they are primarily investigated as a photocatalyst for HER [161,162]. For example, La5Ti2AgS5O7 used as an HEP in conjunction with WO3 as an OEP and an I3 −/I− redox couple as a shuttle mediator, achieved Z-scheme water splitting with an AQY of 0.12% at 420 nm [161]. Additionally, La5Ti2CuS5O7 and La5Ti2Cu0.9Ag0.1S5O7 were further applied in photocatalyst sheets (a type of microscopic tandem cell) for Z-scheme water splitting [163–165]. After careful cocatalyst engineering, the La5Ti2Cu0.9Ag0.1S5O7: Ga|Au|BiVO4:Mo sheet achieved an AQY of 11.8% at 420 nm and an STH of 0.4% at 301 K and 4 kPa [165]. Given their p-type semiconductor characteristics and long absorption-edge wavelengths, La5Ti2CuS5O7 and La5Ti2Cu0.9Ag0.1S5O7 are also widely applied as photocathodes for PEC water splitting [159,166–169]. With various modifications, including cocatalysts loading, element doping, morphology control, and surface protection, these photocathodes have achieved onset potentials as positive as +0.9 V vs. a reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE), although their current densities at 0 V vs. RHE were around 1 mA/cm2. 3 Advanced methodological strategies and techniques in photocatalysis 3.1 Cocatalyst modification 3.1.1 Deposition methods In 1978, Kraeutler et al. [170] reported the in situ photodeposition of Pt nanoparticles on the surface of the anatase-TiO2 using hexachloroplatinic acid (H2PtCl6) as the precursor and acetate as the sacrificial reagent. During this process, photo-induced electrons reduce the metal ions in the solution, forming metallic nanoparticles on the semiconductor surface, while the holes oxidize acetate to evolve CO2. These Pt nanoparticles not only functioned as active sites for catalytic reactions but also played a crucial role in suppressing electron-hole recombination by providing a carrier sink for rapid transfer [171,172]. In situ photodeposition allows for the selective loading of cocatalysts at reaction sites without requiring the activation step that is often necessary for cocatalysts loaded by impregnation. However, in situ photodeposition reactions at the surfaces or interfaces of materials are highly sensitive to the exposed surface atomic structures and their corresponding physicochemical properties. This sensitivity can result in unreliable processes, potentially leading to weak cocatalyst/semiconductor contact, which hampers efficient charge separation and transfer. Additionally, it sometimes formed larger cocatalyst particles with a lower specific surface area, thereby reducing the number of active sites [173]. To address the challenges associated with in situ photodeposition, Domen et al. [123] proposed an innovative approach that combines the impregnation and photodeposition methods for cocatalyst loading. The impregnation method typically disperses cocatalysts randomly on the photocatalyst surface, yet the cocatalysts require activation, such as reduction or oxidation, to gain high activities. In this approach, a photocatalyst like BaTaO2N was initially loaded with Pt cocatalysts using the impregnation method (Pt(imp)/BaTaO2N), followed by heat treatment under a H2 reduction atmosphere to form metallic Pt nanoparticles. Subsequently, photoreduction was employed to deposit additional Pt onto the Pt(imp)/BaTaO2N in the presence of methanol as an electron donor. This process aimed to improve Pt dispersion and create more active sites. The H2 evolution rates of the samples loaded Pt by impregnation (Pt(imp)/BaTaO2N), photodeposition (Pt(pd)/BaTaO2N), and the combination of impregnation and photodeposition (Pt(imp + pd)/BaTaO2N) were compared under visible light irradiation in an aqueous solution containing methanol as the electron donor, with the optimal Pt loading of 0.1 wt% for Pt(imp) and 0.2 wt% for Pt(pd). The AQY of (Pt(imp + pd)/BaTaO2N) was significantly enhanced by over 100 times compared to bare BaTaO2N, reaching 6.8% at a wavelength of 420 nm. Furthermore, when this optimized sample was used as the HEP in a Z-scheme water splitting system, combined with WO3 as the OEP and IO3 −/I− as a redox mediator, simultaneous evolution of H2 and O2 was achieved with an STH of 0.24%. Such a two-step cocatalyst deposition method has proven to be versatile. For instance, the Rh(imp + pd)/Ga-La5Ti2Cu0.9Ag0.1O7S5 sample was observed to produce nearly four times as much H2 as the Rh(pd)/Ga-LTCA sample under the same reaction conditions [174]. 3.1.2 Co-deposition of different cocatalysts During photocatalytic water splitting, asymmetric band bending within photocatalysts directs the movement of photogenerated electrons and holes toward the reductive and oxidative sites, respectively. At these reaction sites, water undergoes reduction to H2 and oxidation to O2, following typical electrochemical processes for hydrogen and oxygen evolution on metals or metal oxides [40,175,176]. In photocatalyst particles with irregular morphology, this asymmetric band bending is induced by loading cocatalysts with a Fermi level or work function different from that of the photocatalyst particles [177]. The effect can be intensified through facet engineering, which exposes crystal facets with varying surface potentials [40]. For optimal efficiency, cocatalysts for H2 and O2 evolution should be selectively loaded onto the corresponding reductive and oxidative crystal facets. This approach enhances asymmetric band bending, promoting charge separation and catalyzing surface reactions effectively. Early research in photocatalytic water splitting primarily focused on loading a single cocatalyst to function as either the H2 or O2 evolution site. Effectively co-depositing both HEC and OEC on a single particle proved challenging, as different cocatalysts can interfere with each other's activity. Domen et al. [77] reported the first example of successful co-deposition of HEC and OEC for effective photocatalytic overall water splitting. In their study, the core/shell structured Rh/Cr2O3 and Mn3O4 nanoparticles were loaded on GaN:ZnO photocatalyst serving as HEC and OEC, respectively. The amorphous Cr2O3 shells effectively suppress the backward reaction, which will be discussed in detail in Section 3.1.3 [178]. As shown in Fig. 12 , the photocatalytic activity for overall water splitting using GaN:ZnO co-loaded with core/shell Rh/Cr2O3 and Mn3O4 was greatly enhanced under visible light irradiation, compared to the sample loaded solely with Rh/Cr2O3 or Mn3O4. The H2 and O2 production rates improved with increasing the amount of Mn3O4 loading, reaching a maximum at 0.05 wt% (relative to the photocatalyst amount), beyond which the water splitting performance declined. The majority of photocatalysts require cocatalysts to drive the H2 and O2 evolution reactions efficiently because the reactions on semiconductors otherwise proceed slowly. The co-loading of OEC and HEC promotes charge separation and provides active sites for both H2 and O2 evolution reactions. This approach represents an effective strategy for enhancing photocatalytic performance and is sometimes indispensable for achieving overall water splitting. The development of co-loading HEC and OEC represents a significant milestone in this field, facilitating the development of new materials for enhanced overall water splitting. It has been successfully employed in various photocatalysts, enabling them to produce both H2 and O2 from water without the need for sacrificial reagents, including TaON, SrTaO2N, Y2Ti2O5S2, as well as the multi-band InGaN nanosheet photochemical diode [88,91–93,179]. The co-loading of different cocatalysts for different redox reactions has shown remarkable versatility, proving effective not only for H2 and O2 evolution reactions but also for other types of reactions [19,180]. For instance, in a visible-light-driven water oxidation reaction using a WO3 photocatalyst in the presence of IO3 − as an electron acceptor, PtO x and RuO2 were co-loaded as cocatalysts. PtO x facilitated the IO3 − reduction reaction to produce I−, while RuO2 promoted the water-to-O2 conversion [180]. Upon the additional loading of RuO2 as the OEC, the O2 evolution rate increased by nearly twice compared to PtO x /WO3. Similar to the co-loading of Rh/Cr2O3 and Mn3O4 on GaN:ZnO, the optimal loading amount of RuO2 on the PtO x (0.5 wt%)/WO3 sample was very small (0.001 wt%). This further supports the observation that the optimal loading amount of a secondary cocatalyst is relatively low, which appears to be a common trend in photocatalysts modified with two different cocatalysts. Photoelectrochemical analyses revealed that the performance of PtO x /WO3 in reducing IO3 − was slightly degraded after co-loading even a small amount of RuO2 (0.001 wt%). With a further increase in the RuO2 co-loading amount, the photoelectrode performance decreased significantly. Therefore, the loading amount of OEC is key to successful co-loading; typically, a small amount of OEC is sufficient to provide oxidation active sites without dramatically compromising the HEC performance. Apparently, the synergistic interaction and spatial segregation of HEC and OEC are crucial for facilitating effective overall water splitting via photocatalysis. Employing facet engineering to direct OEC and HEC to their respective active sites represents an elegant strategy for controlling cocatalyst spatial distribution. The process of photodeposition was observed to cause selective migration of photoexcited electrons and holes to different facets of the photocatalysts, influenced by the active sites and electronic energy levels on different facets [88,91–93]. Li et al. [181,182] demonstrated spatial separation of reduction and oxidation sites on 18-facet SrTiO3 nanocrystals. By optimizing Pt HEC loading on {001} facets and Co3O4 OEC on {110} facets of SrTiO3, they achieved a 5-fold increase in the AQY for photocatalytic water splitting compared to 6-facet SrTiO3 with isotropic facets. The enhanced photocatalytic activity can be attributed to the improved net driving force for charge separation, facilitated by the different built-in electric fields at distinct facets, and the increased symmetry of the surface electric fields due to the asymmetric assembly of cocatalysts. Subsequently, Domen et al. [46] applied a similar strategy to that used by Li et al. [182] for SrTiO3:Al. This involved the selective photodeposition of cocatalysts—Rh/Cr2O3 as the HEC and CoOOH as the OEC—on different crystal facets. This approach utilized anisotropic charge transport, leveraging a charge rectification effect within the photocatalyst particles induced by an internal electric field. As a result, the Rh/Cr2O3 HEC was deposited via reduction on {100} facets, while the CoOOH OEC was deposited via oxidation on {110} facets and adjacent surfaces that collect holes (Fig. 13 ). As a result, the water-splitting reaction was remarkably enhanced, allowing multiple consecutive forward charge transfers without backward charge transfer (Fig. 13(c)). The SrTiO3:Al co-loaded with Rh/Cr2O3 and CoOOH achieved an external quantum efficiency of up to 96% at 350−360 nm (Fig. 13(d)), corresponding to near unity internal quantum efficiency. This study illustrates the potential to eliminate charge recombination through smart and deliberate material design, providing valuable insights for future advancements in this field of research [39,183,184]. 3.1.3 Surface modification for HEC Backward reactions involving molecular oxygen, such as the production of water from generated H2 and O2, as well as the oxygen reduction reaction, present significant challenges during the simultaneous production of H2 and O2 via water-splitting reactions. Additionally, many effective HECs, exemplified by Pt, also effectively catalyze the oxygen reduction reaction through electrocatalytic means. Because the distance between H2 and O2 evolution sites on a photocatalyst particle typically spans several tens of nanometers, the H2 evolution reaction on HEC competes with the backward reaction. Therefore, it is vital to suppress these backward reactions to achieve efficient overall water splitting. To address this issue, Domen team developed an effective strategy by coating the co-catalyst and/or photocatalyst with an oxide layer that functions as a molecular sieve. This coating helps to selectively control the interactions at the interface, improving the overall performance and stability of the photocatalytic system. The first core-shell-structured cocatalyst, NiO/Ni, where the metallic HEC (Ni) was covered by a thin layer of metal oxide (NiO), was reported by Domen et al. [27,45] in the 1980s. They used the impregnation method to deposit NiO onto SrTiO3 particles, resulting in a core/shell Ni/NiO core-shell structure after undergoing reduction and reoxidation treatments (Fig. 14(a) ). Upon calcination of the Ni(NO3)2-SrTiO3 mixture, prepared through impregnation in air, NiO became the predominant species on the SrTiO3 surface, exhibiting negligible activity for water splitting. Reduction with H2 converted NiO primarily to metallic Ni, but the catalyst remained ineffective, with no observable oxygen evolution. Subsequent reoxidation with O2 resulted in the formation of a NiO/Ni cocatalyst with a core-shell structure, which was then capable of decomposing water into H2 and O2 under light irradiation. However, excessive reoxidation at high temperatures caused the metallic Ni to dissipate from the SrTiO3 surface, leaving behind NiO with greatly reduced activity. This highlights the critical role of the structure and valence state of Ni species loaded onto the SrTiO3 surface in determining its photocatalytic activity for the overall water-splitting reaction. During photocatalytic water splitting, the metallic Ni core received electrons from the CB of SrTiO3, providing active sites for HER. Simultaneously, the NiO shell effectively shielded the Ni core from oxygen, thereby preventing backward reactions. Notably, although NiO-loaded SrTiO3 exhibited lower activity for overall water splitting than NiO/Ni-modified SrTiO3, NiO itself is a potent cocatalyst that significantly enhances the activity of some photocatalysts, such as NaTaO3 and KTaO3 [185,186]. One of its notable advantages is its inertness towards the typical backward reaction of water splitting compared to noble metals. However, not all metal species can form permselective thin oxide layers through reduction and reoxidation treatments. Therefore, there is a need to develop universally applicable permselective oxide layers. In industrial electrolysis processes for producing NaClO3 from aqueous salt solutions [187,188], which involve creating a Cr(OH)3·nH2O film that selectively blocks the permeation of large O2 molecules while allowing the passage of protons, water, and H2. Domen et al. [79] examined mixed oxide as cocatalysts and occasionally found that Cr2O3 when co-loaded with other metal oxides, worked as a permselective layer for cocatalysts. This topic will be discussed in more detail later. They in situ photodeposited the Cr2O3 (or Cr(OH)3·nH2O) layer using K2CrO4 as a precursor, covering noble metals (such as Ru, Rh, Pt, and Pd) or metal oxide cocatalysts (such as NiO x , RuO2, and Rh2O3) and to form a core-shell structure [78]. The role of the Cr2O3 layer in photocatalytic water splitting was examined through electrochemical experiments and in situ IRAS measurements. As illustrated in Fig. 14(b), the results confirmed that Cr2O3 acted as a permselective layer, allowing the diffusion of protons and H2 while inhibiting the movement of O2. A subsequent study by Takanabe et al. [189] demonstrated that the Cr2O3 layer was also impermeable to ferricyanide, IO3 –, S2O8 2–, H2O2, and gaseous CO. The surfaces of some photocatalysts, exemplified by LaMg1/3Ta2/3O2N, can also facilitate the backward reactions of water splitting. Applying a Cr2O3 layer to Rh2–y Cr y O3/LaMg1/3Ta2/3O2N was ineffective because this layer was selectively deposited only on the Rh2–y Cr y O3 HEC and not on the LaMg1/3Ta2/3O2N surface [85,190]. As a result, severe backward reactions could still occur on the photocatalyst surface (Fig. 15(a) ), leading to the evolution of H2 and O2 via water splitting in a non-stoichiometric ratio.
