To address this issue, Domen et al. [85] developed the use of an amorphous TiO2 layer (a-TiO2) as a new permselective layer on Rh2–y Cr y O3-loaded LaMg1/3Ta2/3O2N. This approach successfully achieved the steady evolution of H2 and O2 through overall water splitting in an expected 2:1 ratio (Fig. 15(b)). The a-TiO2 layer did not function as a photocatalyst or an electron/hole-transport layer [191]. The H2O molecules and H+ ions in the hydrated a-TiO2 layer acted as reactants during water splitting. H2 and O2 molecules generated on the cocatalyst/photocatalyst were transported across the flexible a-TiO2 layer driven by a pressure gradient. However, the reverse transport of H2 and O2 was not possible due to the higher pressure beneath the oxide layer. This mechanism prevented both O2 reduction and water formation from H2 and O2 (Fig. 14(c)). While an accumulation of H2 at the cocatalyst/photocatalyst interface may increase the overpotential for H2 evolution, slightly decreasing water splitting activity, it did not lead to H2 oxidation on the cocatalyst, as the cocatalyst functioned as a reduction site. Additionally, the high polarity and hydrophilicity of a-TiO2 improved reaction selectivity by suppressing the transfer of less polar (i.e., less hydrophilic) molecules, such as O2, from the reaction solution to the cocatalyst/photocatalyst surface. Oxyhydroxides of additional group IV and V transition metals, such as Zr, Ta, and Nb, also showed the potential to act as permselective amorphous layers akin to a-TiO2, although their effectiveness in enhancing photocatalytic activities varied. In addition to inhibiting the backward reactions, these amorphous layers help stabilize LaMg1/3Ta2/3O2N by preventing self-corrosion. It is believed that the layers facilitate h+ injection into oxygen species within the amorphous layer (i.e. OH groups or hydrated water), thereby suppressing the excessive accumulation of h+ in the nitrogen species on the LaMg1/3Ta2/3O2N surface. 3.1.4 Two-component cocatalysts Pt is widely used as a cocatalyst for H2 evolution on photocatalysts in the presence of electron donors. However, its catalytic activity for backward reactions makes Pt unsuitable for overall water splitting on single particles. In an early study, Domen et al. [83] discovered that the overall photocatalytic water-splitting performance was slightly enhanced after adding Cr to NiO x -loaded K2La2Ti3O10 through the impregnation method. Building on these findings, in 2006, they developed two-component cocatalysts comprising Cr combined with another transition metal, such as Ni, Ru, Rh, Ir, and Pt, to enhance the efficiency of photocatalytic water splitting using (Ga1–x Zn x )(N1–x O x ) photocatalysts [192]. The photocatalytic overall water-splitting activity was significantly enhanced by two orders of magnitude with the introduction of the Rh2–y Cr y O3 cocatalyst compared to using Rh alone. Interestingly, although loading (Ga1–x Zn x )(N1–x O x ) with Fe, Co, Cu, Pd, or Ag alone was not active for overall water splitting, co-loading Cr with one of these otherwise inactive metals resulted in measurable photocatalytic activity. This result indicates that co-loading Cr facilitated charge transfer from the photocatalyst bulk to the cocatalyst and/or to create catalytic sites on the cocatalyst surface. Rh2–y Cr y O3 has been demonstrated as an effective H2 evolution promoter on various photocatalysts including (Ga1–x Zn x )(N1–x O x ), ZnNb2O6, β-Ge3N4, and β-Ga2O3, as evidenced by the higher H2 production rate compared to samples loaded solely with Ni, Rh, RuO2, NiO or left unloaded. The co-loading of Cr was effective not only for enhancing the water-splitting rate but also for suppressing the deactivation of the Ni catalyst, whose chemical states changed during the reaction. Note that the optimal Cr loading varies with the co-loaded transition metal. For example, the optimal Cr amount in Ni (1.25 wt%)-Cr on (Ga1–x Zn x )(N1–x O x ) was 0.125 wt%, while for Rh (1 wt%)-Cr, it was 1.5 wt%. The optimal Cr/metal ratio is also affected by the base photocatalyst; for instance, the Cr optimal amount in Ni (3 wt%)-Cr on K2La2Ti3O10 changed to 0.5 wt%. Studies using time-resolved photoluminescence and transient absorbance spectroscopies have elucidated the charge carrier dynamics of Rh2–y Cr y O3/(Ga1–x Zn x )(N1–x O x ), revealing efficient electron transfer from (Ga1–x Zn x )(N1–x O x ) to Rh2–y Cr y O3 within sub-microsecond timescales [193]. This process is crucial for reducing the electron concentration within (Ga1–x Zn x )(N1–x O x ) and promoting hole accumulation. Importantly, the rates of H2 and O2 evolution from water using Rh2–y Cr y O3-loaded (Ga1–x Zn x )(N1–x O x ) remained nearly unchanged under varying background reaction pressures and in the presence of O2 gas. This indicates that Rh2–y Cr y O3 acted as a cocatalyst for H2 production from protons without facilitating the oxygen reduction reaction [194]. The mechanism behind the oxygen reduction reaction resistance of Rh2–y Cr y O3 has not been fully elucidated. One proposed explanation suggests that within the microstructure of Rh2–y Cr y O3 nanoparticles, Rh species are encapsulated with a thin CrO x overlayer. This overlayer acts to inhibit the reaction of O2 and H2 on Rh species, thereby preventing the consumption of H2 and inhibiting the O2 reduction [89]. Since then, the Rh2–y Cr y O3 cocatalyst has been widely employed on various photocatalyst surfaces, including GaN [130], Ca2Nb2O7 [195], (Zn1+x Ge)(N2O x ) [96], LaMg x Ta1–x O1+3x , and SrTiO3 [12], to facilitate the cleavage of water into H2 and O2. Incorporating Rh2–y Cr y O3 onto the surface of Al-doped SrTiO3 notably enhanced its water-splitting activity, achieving an AQY of 56% ± 3% within the wavelength of 365 nm and an STH of 0.4%. 3.2 Z-scheme system 3.2.1 Early works The photocatalytic overall water-splitting process is a thermodynamically uphill reaction, involving a significant increase in Gibbs free energy (237 kJ/mol at 298 K and 1 atm). This makes it challenging to produce both H2 and O2 simultaneously from water under visible light irradiation using a single photocatalyst. To date, the number of such photocatalysts is still limited [196]. An alternative approach involves constructing a Z-scheme system inspired by the two-step photoexcitation process found in natural photosynthesis in green plants. This Z-scheme photocatalysis system comprises a HEP, an OEP, and typically a shuttle redox couple (electron donor (D)/electron acceptor (A)) to mediate electron transfer between these two photocatalysts, as illustrated in Fig. 16(a) . In such a Z-scheme system, both the HEP and OEP generate electrons and holes upon light absorption. The electrons in HEP reduce water to H2, while the holes oxidize the electron donor (D) of the redox couple, producing the electron acceptor (A) as an oxidation product. Conversely, the holes in the VB of OEP oxidize water, generating O2 and reducing the electron acceptor (A) back to electron donor (D), achieving the overall water-splitting reaction [197–199]. The Z-scheme system effectively balances the need for a wide bandgap to drive water splitting with the requirement for visible light absorption to effectively utilize solar energy. This approach also allows for the use of semiconductors with suitable water reduction or oxidation potentials, thereby reducing both the energy needed for each reaction and the material requirements. The concept of a “dual n-type semiconductor model” based on two-step photoexcitation and the use of a redox couple as the electron transport chain was proposed by Bard in 1979 [200]. However, validating Z-scheme water-splitting systems has been challenging for a long time, primarily due to mismatches between the HEP and OEP, as well as between these photocatalysts and the redox mediators. Additionally, issues arise from side and backward reactions caused by these redox species. A prototype for Z-scheme photocatalytic water splitting was achieved by Sayama et al. [201] in 1997. In this study, RuO2-loaded WO3 served as the OEP, producing O2 from water in the presence of Fe3+ ions as electron acceptors. Simultaneously, H2 was generated by reducing protons in a photochemical process facilitated by the excitation of Fe2+ ions under UV light, accompanied by the oxidation of Fe2+ to form Fe3+. Stoichiometric evolution of H2 and O2 from water was achieved using this Z-scheme approach, despite employing only one photocatalyst combined with a photochemical process. In 2001, the first Z-scheme system employing dual photocatalytic blocks was developed by the same group [202]. It utilized Cr and Ta co-doped SrTiO3 as HEP, WO3 as OEP, and IO3 −/I− as a redox mediator, achieving an AQY of approximately 0.1% at 420 nm for overall water splitting. Inspired by such progress, Domen and his team [203,204] successfully developed effective photocatalytic Z-scheme water-splitting systems using various semiconductors. They discovered that the preferential selectivity of a photocatalyst towards water oxidation or reduction reaction was a key factor in establishing an effective Z-scheme system. For instance, Abe et al. [197] found that rutile TiO2 selectively adsorbed IO3 − while inhibiting the absorption of I−, leading to the selective oxidation of water over I− oxidation. Similar adsorption preferences were observed for Fe3+ ions on rutile TiO2, which favored water oxidation to produce O2 even in the presence of electron donors Fe2+. This preference arose because Fe3+ ions were more readily adsorbed on TiO2 compared to Fe2+ ions, thereby facilitating efficient water oxidation [205]. These findings highlight the importance of semiconductor photocatalyst surface states and their adsorption selectivity for redox ions in determining the performance of photocatalytic water-splitting reactions. 3.2.2 Z-scheme water splitting using narrow bandgap semiconductors Domen and his team utilized various (oxy)nitrides and oxysulfides with narrow bandgaps as photocatalysts in the Z-scheme for water splitting, aiming to enhance the effective utilization of visible light. The first instance of employing an oxynitride photocatalyst for Z-scheme water splitting was reported in 2002, utilizing Pt-loaded TaON as the HEP, Pt-loaded WO3 as the OEP, and IO3 −/I− as the shuttle redox couple [206]. Shortly thereafter, partially oxidized PtO x was introduced onto WO3 as a cocatalyst to enhance the reduction of IO3 −, thereby promoting O2 evolution. This modification resulted in achieving an AQY of approximately 0.4% at 420 nm in the established (Pt/TaON)|(IO3 −/I−)|(PtO x /WO3) Z-scheme system [207]. In 2010, Domen et al. [171] reported significant advancements in Z-scheme water-splitting systems using an efficient ZrO2/TaON HEP. They successfully suppressed electron-hole recombination in TaON through ZrO2 modification [103], pairing it with various OEPs such as Pt/WO3, rutile TiO2, RuO2/TaON, or BiVO4, along with shuttle redox mediators (IO3 −/I− or Fe3+/Fe2+). Their study highlights the critical importance of facilitating both proton reduction and oxidation of electron-donating ions on ZrO2/TaON for achieving effective overall water splitting. Thus, precise modification with cocatalysts and control of reaction conditions is vital. Among the combinations tested, Pt/ZrO2/TaON|IO3 −/I−|Pt/WO3 exhibited the highest activity because these components effectively drove forward reactions involving the redox couple (e.g., oxidation of I− on Pt/ZrO2/TaON and reduction of IO3 − on Pt/WO3), thereby minimizing undesired backward reactions, as illustrated in Fig. 16(b). Under optimal conditions, the system achieved an AQY of 6.3% at 420.5 nm, setting a new benchmark for visible-light-driven Z-scheme water splitting using particulate photocatalysts at that time. The performance of the system was further improved in subsequent work by Zhang and Li et al. [106] by replacing ZrO2/TaON with a MgTa2O6–x N y /TaON heterostructure as the HEP, achieving an AQY of 6.8% at 420 nm, setting a new record for Z-scheme overall water splitting in powder suspension form at that time. Domen et al. [120] demonstrated the versatility of the Z-scheme system construction strategy by successfully applying a series of perovskite-type mixed tantalum oxynitrides, specifically ATaO2N (where A = Ca, Sr, Ba) with the light absorption edges of 520, 600, and 660 nm, respectively. For instance, utilizing Pt/BaTaO2N as the HEP in conjunction with PtO x /WO3 as the OEP, and the IO3 −/I− redox couple, enabled the first realization of Z-scheme water splitting with a light-response range extending to 600 nm for HER. In Domen's recent research, single nanocrystals of ATaO2N (A = Sr, Ca, Ba) with excellent crystallinity and tunable long-wavelength responsiveness were successfully synthesized through thermal nitridation of mixtures of tantalum disulfide, metal hydroxides (A(OH)2), and molten-salt fluxes (e.g., SrCl2) as precursors [208]. These nanocrystals exhibited enhanced photocatalytic H2 or O2 evolution in the presence of sacrificial reagents, positioning them as promising candidates for developing Z-scheme water-splitting systems. For example, after modifying SrTaO2N with Ir-Pt alloy/Cr2O3 and combining it with Ir-CoFeO x /BiVO4 OEP and [Fe(CN)6]3−/[Fe(CN)6]4− redox mediator, an STH of 0.15% was achieved in a Z-scheme overall water splitting process [124]. Domen team emphasized the crucial role of cocatalyst modification in enhancing selectivity towards desired reactions. For instance, when TaON was exposed to an aqueous solution containing IO3 − under visible light irradiation, minimal O2 evolution occurred due to the preferential oxidation of I−, which was produced through the reduction of IO3 −. However, upon loading RuO2 nanoparticles onto the surface of TaON, the rate of O2 evolution was dramatically enhanced in aqueous IO3 − solution. Interestingly, RuO2/TaON exhibited reduced performance for OER in the presence of Ag+ as the electron acceptor compared to bare TaON, indicating that RuO2 primarily suppresses I− oxidation, thereby effectively improving its selectivity towards water oxidation [208]. Basis on it, the Pt/TaON and RuO2/TaON photocatalysts were employed as HEP and OEP, respectively, and were found to enable simultaneous evolution of H2 and O2 in an aqueous NaI solution under visible light (λ > 420 nm). In 2013, Domen et al. [151] pioneered the use of an oxysulfide capable of absorbing light up to approximately 650 nm for Z-scheme water splitting. Pt-loaded Sm2Ti2S2O5 suspended with rutile TiO2 (OEP) in an aqueous NaI solution successfully split water into H2 and O2 under UV irradiation (λ > 300 nm). Visible light-driven Z-scheme water splitting into H2 and O2 was achieved by replacing TiO2 with WO3, which was responsive to visible light, and using I3 −/I− as a shuttle electron mediator. The WO3 was treated with H+ and Cs+ and loaded with PtO x as the cocatalyst for I3 − reduction to I− [154]. Additionally, various other narrow-bandgap oxysulfide photocatalysts with HER activity, such as La5Ti2CuS5O7 and La6Ti2S8O5, have also been demonstrated to function effectively as HEP in similar Z-scheme water splitting systems. Redox mediators present in the reaction solution can induce side reactions, such as the reduction of oxidized mediators on the HEP and the oxidation of reduced mediators on the OEP (Fig. 16(b)), potentially leading to low water splitting efficiency. Therefore, a redox-mediator-free Z-scheme water-splitting system is highly desirable [209]. In such systems, achieving efficient electron transfer from the OEP to the HEP is crucial. To address this, solid-state electron mediators such as reduced graphene oxide (RGO), carbon, Au, and indium tin oxide (ITO) have been employed [196,198]. The first example was reported by Kudo et al. [210], who achieved Z-scheme overall water splitting by using RGO as a bridge to facilitate interparticle electron transfer between the HEP (Ru/SrTiO3:Rh) and the OEP (BiVO4). More recently, Domen et al. [152] employed the RGO as a solid-state mediator to enhance electron transfer between a HEP composed of Cr2O3/Pt/IrO2-loaded Sm2Ti2O5S2 and a CoO x -loaded BiVO4 OEP. This approach marked a significant advancement in photocatalytic overall water splitting performance compared to previous powder suspension systems using redox couples [151,154], achieved an AQY of 7.0% at 420 nm and an STH of 0.22% (Fig. 17 ). Subsequently, it was demonstrated that carbon nanotubes are also effective as solid-state mediators in the Cr2O3/Pt/Sm2Ti2O5S2/IrO2|carbon nanotube|CoO x /BiVO4 system for photocatalytic overall water splitting in a Z-scheme configuration. Based on the high stability and excellent charge transfer characteristics of carbon nanotubes, stoichiometric amounts of H2 and O2 evolved at near-ambient pressure, achieving an STH of 0.15% [211]. While solid-state mediators generally facilitate interparticle electron transfer, they can also lead to photoexcited electron-hole recombination and undesired back reactions, such as the oxygen reduction reaction, occurring on their surfaces. The representative Z-scheme water-splitting systems developed by the Domen team are summarized in Table 3 . 3.3 Preparation/fabrication techniques 3.3.1 Synthesis methods The structural and electronic properties of a photocatalyst, including its morphology, crystallinity, and defect density, are significantly influenced by the synthesis method. To prepare visible-light-responsive (oxy)nitride and (oxy)sulfide photocatalysts, Domen et al. [100,114] developed thermal nitridation/ sulfurization processes, as well as sealed-tube reactions. During thermal nitridation/sulfurization, the oxide precursor is annealed in a flow of NH3 or H2S, typically yielding single-phase and crystalline (oxy)nitride photocatalysts such as TaON and LaTiO2N. However, (oxy)sulfide photocatalysts, such as Y2Ti2O5S2 and La5Ti2Cu0.9Ag0.1O7S5, are often produced with impurities [174,217,218]. The highly reductive nature of H2S during thermal sulfurization necessitates precise control of the reaction time to avoid low crystallinity in the products. A common challenge in thermal nitridation and sulfurization is achieving stoichiometric products due to deficiencies in nitrogen or sulfur. In contrast, sealed-tube reactions, where stoichiometric precursors undergo a long-term solid-state reaction in an oxygen-free environment, are more effective in producing stoichiometric products [92,167]. However, this method, which typically involves high temperatures (e.g., 1000 °C) for extended periods (e.g., 100 h), often results in microscale, polycrystalline particles with structural defects, which are less ideal for photocatalytic applications. Moreover, sealed-tube reactions are more commonly used for synthesizing (oxy)sulfides than (oxy)nitrides, as stable nitride precursors are often unavailable [76]. To improve the crystallinity and control the morphology of the products, molten fluxes can be employed to assist the synthesis processes [70,88,91,105]. The flux, typically composed of alkaline or alkaline earth salt mixtures, is removed through post-washing. For instance, using CaCl2 as a flux in sealed-tube reactions significantly reduced the preparation time of Y2Ti2O5S2 compared to solid-state reactions [219]. The resulting Y2Ti2O5S2 exhibited smaller particle size and improved crystallinity, which enhanced both H2 and O2 evolution. The choice of flux is crucial to prevent impurity formation; for example, CsCl was avoided in the preparation of Y2Ti2O5S2 because alkali metal ions can easily intercalate into the Y2Ti2O5S2 structure. Template-assisted methods have also been explored to prepare photocatalyst particles with unique shapes [220,221]. As illustrated in Fig. 18(a) , Pt was first deposited on SiO2 particles, followed by the coating of Ta2O5 on Pt/SiO2 using a sol-gel method. After nitridation, Ta2O5 was converted to Ta3N5, and IrO2 or CoO x was deposited on the Ta3N5 surface via adsorption or impregnation. This resulted in a core/shell SiO2/Ta3N5 structure, with Pt nanoparticles on the inner Ta3N5 shell surface acting as an electron collector and IrO2 or CoO x on the outer shell surface serving as a hole collector. This core/shell structure provided a larger surface area and more active sites compared to a bulk structure. Furthermore, the spatial separation of cocatalysts promoted the separation and migration of photogenerated electrons and holes to the inner and outer surfaces, respectively, thereby reducing charge recombination and backward reactions. Although the core/shell SiO2/Ta3N5 structure with spatially separated cocatalysts significantly improved sacrificial H2 and O2 evolution (Figs. 18(b,c)), it was still limited in its ability to perform overall water splitting, likely due to the suboptimal chemical properties of the components used in its preparation. In addition to thermal nitridation/sulfurization and sealed-tube reactions, the crystal structure, morphology, and stoichiometry of oxide precursors significantly influence the photocatalytic activities of (oxy)nitride and (oxy)sulfide photocatalysts. In the Domen group, oxide precursors are typically synthesized using solid-state reactions, polymerized complex method, or a homogeneous precipitation method [85,87,222–224]. The solid-state reaction involves mixing metal oxides or salts and heating them at high temperatures to promote diffusion and reaction, leading to the formation of the desired oxide. This method is advantageous for its simplicity and the production of highly crystalline materials; however, achieving uniformity can be challenging, and the resulting particles exhibit noticeable grain boundaries. The polymerized complex method forms a polymeric network from metal ions and organic ligands, which decomposes upon calcination to produce oxides with controlled crystallinity and particle size [225,226]. This method is beneficial for producing nanoscale oxides with high surface areas, and critical for enhancing photocatalytic performance, though it may leave behind residual carbon impurities. The homogeneous precipitation method involves the gradual release of precipitating agents, such as NaOH, to form metal hydroxide mixtures in solution. These mixtures are then thoroughly washed to remove alkaline metal ions. Upon calcination, these intermediates decompose into oxides with fine particle sizes and uniform distribution. This method is particularly effective for synthesizing oxides with tailored stoichiometry and morphology, which are essential for optimizing the photocatalytic properties of the final (oxy)nitride or (oxy)sulfide materials. 3.3.2 Particle transfer method PEC cells designed for water splitting require semiconductor materials that efficiently capture a wide spectrum of solar radiation, enable rapid charge transfer at the semiconductor/liquid interface, and exhibit long-term stability. To meet these criteria, effective setups often adopt a multilayer film configuration where light-absorbing and surface production materials are similar to those used in solar cells, but submerged within an aqueous electrolyte [9]. Therefore, solar PEC water splitting faces challenges before solar hydrogen can compete with fossil fuels on a cost-per-energy basis. Substantial effort has been devoted to the fabrication of photoelectrodes based on cost-effective and high-crystallinity semiconductor powders, which can typically be synthesized on a large scale easily, such as squeegeeing [227], screen-printing [228], spraying [229] and electrophoretic deposition [230,231]. However, the photoelectrodes produced in this manner suffer from inefficient electronic contact between semiconductor particles and conductive substrates, resulting in high resistance and low photocurrent. To overcome these challenges and improve PEC performance and mechanical strength, “post-necking” treatment is commonly employed [232,233]. For instance, Abe et al. [234,235] utilized TiCl4 and heat treatments to form TiO2 between TaON particles, thereby bridging the particles and enhancing the interparticle electron transport. Nonetheless, this approach is not always practical, as identifying a suitable “post-necking” material and procedure for a specific photoelectrode material can be challenging. Moreover, the formation of multilayers of semiconductor particles increases the number of boundaries for carrier migration, which can hinder performance. To overcome these challenges, Domen et al. [234] pioneered the particle transfer method. This innovative technique is straightforward, versatile, and scalable, offering an alternative approach to traditional photoelectrode fabrication methods. The particle transfer method, illustrated in Fig. 19(a) , uses LaTiO2N as an example. Initially, LaTiO2N particles suspended in isopropanol are drop-casted on a glass substrate and dried. A thin metal layer (100–300 nm) is then coated on the particle layer using the radio-frequency magnetron sputtering method, ensuring ohmic contact with the semiconductors. Subsequently, another metal film, a few microns thick, is deposited using the sputtering method to provide sufficient conductivity and mechanical strength. A second glass substrate is then bonded to the layers with epoxy resin, after which the first glass layer is peeled off. Finally, excess particle layers are removed through ultrasonication in water, leaving only a monolayer of particles remaining on the surface. This method significantly improved the electrical contact between the substrate with semiconductor particles, reducing the barrier to charge transfer. Metals with high tolerance to aqueous electrolytes across a wide pH range, such as Ta, Nb, Ti, and Zr, are commonly used as contact and conductor layers [201]. In this study, the IrO2-loaded LaTiO2N photoanode, utilizing Ta as the contact layer and Ti as the conductor layer, achieved the highest photocurrent among the photoelectrodes examined using various contact and conductor layers (e.g., Ta, Nb, Ti, and Zr). Furthermore, the photocurrent was significantly enhanced compared to LaTiO2N electrodes prepared using a conventional simple coating of LaTiO2N particles on a fluorine-doped tin oxide (FTO) substrate. Gas product analysis showed a Faradaic efficiency of approximately 100% for OER using the LaTiO2N photoanode prepared via the particle transfer method. The particle transfer method has been demonstrated as an effective and versatile approach for preparing efficient photoelectrodes, including both photoanodes and photocathodes. For instance, La5Ti2CuS5O7 photocathodes prepared using the particle transfer method with a Pt contact layer and an Au conductor layer exhibited photocathodic currents at 0 V vs. RHE ten times greater than those of samples fabricated via pulsed laser deposition methods [167]. Similarly, the Co-loaded BaTaO2N photoanode coated with Ta|Ti metal films as contact and conductor layers, achieved a half-cell STH efficiency of 0.7% at 1.0 V vs. RHE under simulated sunlight irradiation (AM 1.5G, 100 mW/cm2) [236], as shown in Fig. 20(a) . This efficiency represented an order of magnitude improvement over previous reports for BaTaO2N prepared using a combination of electrophoretic deposition and post-necking methods [237]. The Faradaic efficiency of this PEC system for OER remained nearly 100% over 6 h (Fig. 20(b)). Apart from its application in fabricating photoelectrodes for HER or OER, the particle transfer method has been extended to establish scalable photocatalyst sheets for solar-light-driven overall water splitting, which will be discussed in Section 3.3.5 [13]. The particle transfer method ingeniously bridges two distinct worlds: particulate photocatalysts and compact, panel-structured photoelectrodes, making it possible to integrate cost-effective and mass-produced photocatalyst powders into efficient PEC systems. Traditional photoelectrodes made from semiconductor powders typically suffer from low photocurrents due to poor contact between the semiconductor and substrate, which leads to significant charge carrier recombination. This method addresses that challenge by fixing photocatalyst particles onto a conductive layer, forming a single layer of photocatalyst with an Ohmic contact at the semiconductor/metal interface and thus enhancing carrier extraction and significantly reducing recombination. The particle transfer method has revolutionized the development of advanced photoelectrodes, particularly benefiting the fabrication of electrodes made from complex semiconductors like oxynitrides and oxysulfides, which are challenging to produce as thin films using traditional techniques. Photoelectrodes fabricated using the particle transfer method have demonstrated performance on par with those made from uniform thin films. For example, a BiVO4 photoanode modified with NiO and CoO x prepared using the particle transfer method, showed similar water oxidation performance for oxygen production as photoelectrodes grown directly on FTO substrates via chemical reactions, achieving a half-cell STH of 1.5% [238,239]. However, due to the single-layer structure of these semiconductors, the light absorption capacity of samples produced via the particle transfer method can be limited, much like in thin-film photoelectrodes. Optimizing the thickness of these layers remains a significant challenge. 3.3.3 Film transfer method The n-type T3N5 semiconductor shows promise as a photoanode for PEC water oxidation due to its simple composition, narrow bandgap (2.1 eV), and suitable band structure. However, powder-based T3N5 photoanodes prepared by electrophoretic deposition suffer from inefficient electronic contact between the thick semiconductor particles and the conductive substrates at the interface [240,241]. Alternatively, Ta3N5 photoelectrodes, when grown as thin films or nanorods on conductive substrates like Ta foil, have shown improved PEC performance [242,243]. Nonetheless, Ta substrates proved to be non-durable under high-temperature treatments when researchers attempted to adjust film thickness and fabricate multiple-layer structures to enhance PEC activity [240,241,244]. Inspired by the particle transfer method used to assemble particulate semiconductors into photoelectrodes, Domen et al. [240,241] introduced a thin film transfer technique for fabricating Ta3N5 photoanodes. This method allowed for precise control over film thickness and optimization of synthesis conditions. The procedure of the film transfer method is shown in Fig. 19(c). Thin Ta films, for example, 570 nm thick, are deposited onto Si substrates using radio-frequency magnetron sputtering at a substrate temperature of 500 °C. After deposition, the Ta|Si samples undergo oxidation at 700 °C for 2 h in air to form Ta2O5 films. Subsequently, the Ta2O5|Si are nitride in gaseous NH3 at 900 °C for 2 h to produce Ta3N5 thin films on the Si substrates. Following this, layers of Ta (150 nm) and Ti (approximately 5 μm) are sputtered onto the as-nitrided Ta3N5 thin films. Finally, the Ta3N5|Ta|Ti films are successfully peeled away from the Si substrates using mechanical exfoliation [240,241]. The resulting porous Ta3N5 films can be uniformly transferred from the Si substrates by the Ta|Ti layers and form an intimate ohmic contact with the metal layer. The Faradaic efficiency of the Ta3N5|Ta|Ti film for PEC water oxidation under AM 1.5G simulated sunlight was confirmed to be nearly 100% through quantification of the evolved O2 (Fig. 21 (a) ). The thin film transfer method enables precise control over the thickness of Ta3N5 films and the formation of multilayer structures within the Ta3N5 film. For example, by introducing a niobium nitride (NbN x ) layer at the interface between the Ta3N5 film and the conductive substrate (Ta|Ti) using this technique, the photocurrent density at 1.23 V vs. RHE was enhanced compared to a Ta3N5|Ta|Ti photoelectrode. The introduction of the NbN x layer facilitated the formation of a 200 nm thick oriented Ta3N5 grain layer near the interlayer, thereby enhancing electron transport throughout the Ta3N5 film (Fig. 21(b)) [246]. These studies offer a method for preparing standalone film-structured photoelectrodes, which can be used in a range of applications, including the development of flexible or floating devices for future needs. The films can also be integrated with various substrates, such as solar cells to create “artificial leaf” devices or with photocathodes to fabricate wireless PEC cells. Nonetheless, the application of the film transfer method is currently limited to simple compounds due to the specialized film preparation process. To date, Ta3N5 photoanodes are the only examples reported using this technique, highlighting the need for modifications in the synthesis to enhance its versatility. 3.3.4 Roll-press method Domen et al. [247], in collaboration with Watanabe from Meiji University, developed another cost-effective, vacuum-free, readily accessible, and scalable approach known as the roll-press method for fixing particulate semiconductor powder and forming photoelectrodes. Taking the preparation of Ta3N5|Ti (Ta3N5 photoelectrode on metal Ti substrate) photoanode as an example, Ta3N5 particles are first coated on a Ti foil through a drop-casting process, followed by drying in the air (Fig. 19(d)). Subsequently, a roll-press process is conducted using two cylindrical rollers rotating against each other at a specific force and rolling speed. The roll-press method is able to control the amount of the semiconductor powder on the photoelectrodes by adjusting the processing amount of the particles and roll-press force. The crystallinity of Ta3N5 particles was preserved when applying a moderate roll-press force (below 10 kN). Photoanodes made of Co-Pi-decorated Ta3N5|Ti using the roll-press method exhibited higher photocurrent densities compared to those prepared using conventional coating methods with post-necking treatment. This highlights the roll-press method is a promising approach for fabricating photoelectrodes from temperature-sensitive semiconductors. Importantly, the Co-Pi/Ta3N5|Ti photoelectrodes scaled up to 3 × 20 cm2 using the roll-press process showed PEC performance in OER comparable to smaller-sized samples (1 × 2 cm2). This performance was also comparable to Co(OH) x /Ta3N5|Nb|Ti photoelectrodes fabricated using the thin film transfer method [245]. The roll-press method offers an affordable, straightforward, and commercially viable approach for fabricating photoelectrodes and photocatalytic sheets. It is particularly advantageous for industrial production due to its low energy consumption and the absence of vacuum processes. However, the performance of photoelectrodes produced by this method currently falls short compared to those made using the particle transfer method [247,248], likely due to insufficient contact between the substrate and semiconductors. Despite being superior to photoelectrodes made using conventional coating methods with post-necking treatment, further optimizations are required. Future work should focus on improving particle size, adjusting the exposure facets of the particulate semiconductors, and refining the atmosphere and temperature conditions during the roll-press process to enhance performance. 3.3.5 Photocatalyst sheets Redox-mediator-free Z-scheme systems can be established by aggregating photocatalyst particles through pH adjustment, which generates attractive electrostatic forces between them [192]. However, despite this approach, the contact between photocatalysts often remains inadequate for efficient interparticle charge transfer, leading to performance that lags behind redox-containing Z-scheme systems. While enhancing interparticle charge transfer through composite combinations of photocatalysts, such as growing one type onto another or annealing their mixture, may seem promising, these methods frequently compromise the photocatalytic activity of each component, ultimately leading to Z-scheme systems that demonstrate only moderate performance [249]. This type of Z-scheme system can be likened to micro-sized parallel p|n photoelectrodes, where efficient operation requires HEPs and OEPs to be p- and n-type semiconductors, respectively. Furthermore, their cathodic and anodic photocurrents must overlap at a specific potential to achieve unbiased water splitting. All-solid-state Z-scheme systems employing materials like RGO or ITO as interparticle mediators have been developed to connect HEP (e.g., metal-doped SrTiO3) and OEP (e.g., BiVO4) [210,250]. However, interparticle charge transfer remains limited due to weak physical contact between photocatalysts and the solid mediator, typically achieved through adsorption or compression. To overcome these hurdles, the Domen group has developed photocatalyst sheets fixing HEP and OEP particles onto a conductive layer to improve the contacts between photocatalysts and the solid mediator. The photocatalyst sheet was developed based on the particle transfer method (Fig. 19(b)) [13]. The process begins by mixing HEP and OEP powder in suspension and drop-casting them onto a glass substrate. Subsequently, a thin conductive layer (c.a. 300 nm), such as Au, is deposited onto the photocatalyst layer using vacuum vapor deposition or sputtering. Finally, the conductive layer with immobilized photocatalysts is peeled off from the primary glass plate by attaching it to another glass plate. This approach facilitates an intimate mechanical and electrical connection between the photocatalysts and the conductive layer, leading to enhanced charge transfer efficiency within the Z-scheme system. Additionally, the micrometer-scale spacing between photocatalysts effectively minimizes solution resistance and concentration overpotentials. Therefore, unlike redox-mediator-free powder suspension Z-scheme systems, the photocatalytic activity of these photocatalyst sheets remained nearly unaffected by the pH of the reaction solution [213,251]. This suggests that electron transfer predominantly occurred through the conductive layer rather than through particle aggregates. The conductive layer effectively bridged the HEP and OEP, prompting efficient electron transfer and thus enhancing overall water-splitting activity. For instance, a photocatalyst sheet comprising La,Rh-codoped SrTiO3 and Mo-doped BiVO4 on an Au or C layer achieved an STH of above 1.0% with an AQY exceeding 30% at 420 nm in pure water (Fig. 22 ) [13,214], which was the new benchmark for sunlight-driven photocatalytic water splitting at that time. Domen et al. [215], in collaboration with TOTO Ltd., have also developed printable photocatalyst sheets for efficient and scalable photocatalytic pure water splitting, as illustrated in Fig. 19(e). These sheets utilized SrTiO3:La,Rh as the HEP, BiVO4 as the OEP, and nanoparticulate Au or ITO as the conductive mediator. The sheets with large active areas (30 × 30 cm), were easily prepared via screen printing technique. Compared to systems using Au nanoparticles as the conductive mediator, SrTiO3:La,Rh|ITO|BiVO4 sheets leverage the unique properties of ITO nanoparticles, such as high visible light transparency and low electrochemical activity during oxygen reduction. Consequently, printable SrTiO3:La,Rh|ITO|BiVO4 sheets achieved water decomposition with an STH efficiency of 0.4%, demonstrating effective solar hydrogen production without the need for vacuum processes for device preparation. The design of the photocatalyst sheet enables the application of various photocatalysts in constructing Z-scheme systems, as the choice of materials is not restricted by surface charge considerations at the working pH. This capability has facilitated the demonstration of Z-scheme overall water splitting using a variety of narrow bandgap photocatalysts, including La5Ti2Cu0.9Ag0.1O7S5, LaMg1/3Ta2/3O2N, and (ZnSe)0.5(CuGa2.5Se4.25)0.5, within a photocatalyst sheet configuration [164,165,212,216]. The application of such sheets has been easily extended to other photosynthetic processes, such as CO2 reduction, by replacing the HEC with CO2 reduction cocatalysts [18,252]. This broadens the scope of photocatalyst sheet technology beyond water splitting, showcasing its potential in sustainable energy and environmental applications. The standalone and wireless photocatalyst sheet systems offer a unique hybrid of conventional Z-scheme photocatalytic and photoelectrochemical systems, combining the best features of both approaches: (1) the low-cost advantage of synthesizing photocatalyst powders and close proximity of reduction and oxidation reactions. This minimizes pH gradients and IR drops, allowing for their operation with high efficiency in pure water without requiring pH adjustments, redox mediators, electrolytes, or buffering agents. As a result, these sheets demonstrate comparable water-splitting activity in pure water, irrespective of their size; (2) the effective contact between the semiconductor and the conductive layer, akin to photoelectrodes, promotes electron transfer between H2 and O2 evolution photocatalysts, significantly enhancing water-splitting performance compared to powder suspension systems. One notable example of this design is a photocatalyst sheet using two n-type materials, which stands apart from typical PEC cells and Z-scheme systems with composite combinations of an HEP and an OEP [212,253]. In this case, RhCrO x /LaMg1/3Ta2/3O2N serves as the HEP and BiVO4:Mo acts as the OEP, both in contact with a gold layer (RhCrO x /LaMg1/3Ta2/3O2N|Au|BiVO4:Mo sheet). Given that LaMg1/3Ta2/3O2N is a photocatalyst capable of splitting water into H2 and O2 on its own, the success of this sheet design is possibly attributed to the unique band bending of LaMg1/3Ta2/3O2N, which facilitates effective electron transfer to the RhCrO x HEC. Nonetheless, as with photoelectrodes fabricated using the particle transfer method, the semiconductor particle layer on these high-performing photocatalyst sheets remains thin, limiting their light absorption capacity. Techniques such as drop-casting and screen printing, which incorporate conductive nanoparticles as electron transfer mediators, can increase the particle layer thickness and improve light harvesting. However, the water-splitting performance is still lower than that obtained using the particle transfer method, primarily due to light shielding by the nanoparticles and less effective contact between the semiconductors and the conductive mediator. Further optimization and modification are needed to overcome these challenges. 3.3.6 Panel and solar H2 production farm Photocatalytic water splitting has conventionally been achieved using powder suspensions, where functional photocatalyst powders are often dispersed in reaction solutions and stirred to ensure sufficient mass transfer. However, using such suspensions presents challenges in terms of dispersal, separation, and scalability for large-scale, real-world applications. To address these issues, researchers have shifted towards fabricating water splitting panels where the photocatalytic powder is securely fixed onto specific substrates [254]. This approach not only resolves issues related to dispersion and recycling but also simplifies sample handling in practical operations [254]. Moreover, economic analyses suggest that designing photocatalyst panels to efficiently track the sun and maximizing the direct radiation capture throughout the day, could offer cost advantages over fixed panel arrays [255]. The first example of a photocatalyst sheet for overall water splitting was reported by Domen et al. [80] using Rh2−y Cr y O3/(Ga1−x Zn x )(N1−x O x ) photocatalyst in 2013. The photocatalyst panel was fabricated by simply drop-casting Rh2−y Cr y O3/(Ga1−x Zn x )(N1−x O x ) powder onto a 5 × 5 cm2 flat frosted glass plate. To enhance mass transport, including water reactant and produced gas, micrometer-sized SiO2 was added to the photocatalyst ink before drop-casting. This addition increased the porosity of the photocatalyst layer, allowing more efficient mass diffusion through the layer. Incorporating SiO2 during the preparation of the Rh2−y Cr y O3/(Ga1−x Zn x )(N1−x O x ) sheet was crucial for maintaining the inherent activity of the powder suspension. In 2018, Domen et al. [12] developed a scalable water splitting panel reactor for photocatalytic overall water splitting. As shown in Fig. 23 , the 1 × 1 m2 reactor comprises photocatalyst sheets fabricated by drop-casting Rh2−y Cr y O3-loaded SrTiO3:Al particles onto glass plates, housed within an outer frame made of acrylic plates. The water splitting panel demonstrated water-splitting activity comparable to that of the powder suspension by using SiO2 nanoparticles (ca. 20 nm in diameter) as an inorganic binder to securely fix the photocatalyst layer onto the substrate. The water splitting panel was tilted at an angle of 10°–20° to ensure the prompt release of evolved gases and to optimize the acceptance angle for sunlight. A hydrophilic window was found to be effective in preventing the accumulation of an explosive H2 and O2 gas mixture within the panel. A water layer depth of 1 mm was sufficient for releasing gas bubbles and ensuring optimal performance, even under elevated light intensity. Importantly, even at such a large scale (1 × 1 m2) and ambient pressure, the intrinsic activity of the Rh2−y Cr y O3-loaded SrTiO3:Al photocatalyst was retained without deterioration, achieving an STH of 0.4% under natural sunlight irradiation (Figs. 23(c) and (d)). This work represents a breakthrough in photocatalytic water splitting, demonstrating that the concept of a water splitting panel is a viable means for large-scale, low-cost renewable solar H2 production. Photocatalytic water splitting panels can essentially be arranged in arrays for scalable solar H2 production farms. Extending from the 1 m2 panel reactor, Domen team reported the safe operation of a 100 m2 array of photocatalyst panels over several months [15]. As depicted in Fig. 24 , the 100 m2 scale prototype for photocatalytic solar-driven H2 production consists of 1600 reactor units arranged in series and was built at the Kakioka Research Facility within the University of Tokyo. Each reactor unit features a light-absorbing area of 625 cm2, with a 0.1 mm gap between the ultraviolet-transparent glass window to minimize water loading and prevent ignition of the gas mixture. In this system, polyurethane tubes are utilized to facilitate gas and water transport. The photocatalyst water-splitting panels were fabricated by spraying a slurry of Rh2–y Cr y O3/CoO x -loaded SrTiO3:Al particles, colloidal silica, and calcium chloride, onto flat and clear glass sheets. The 100-m2 solar H2 production farm achieved H2 generation under natural sunlight conditions, enabling an STH efficiency of 0.76% during optimal summer sunshine conditions. The gaseous oxyhydrogen product from the 100-m2 photocatalyst panel reactor was fed to a gas-separating membrane unit via gas collection and transportation tubes, recycling 73% produced hydrogen recovery using a commercial membrane. Domen and his team demonstrated solar hydrogen production through photocatalytic water splitting, including the safe separation of H2 from the moist gas mixture, to operate reliably over several months. These achievements mark a significant milestone in the field, representing the first demonstration of real-world hydrogen production through photocatalytic overall water splitting at a scale of 100 m2. It stands as the largest solar hydrogen production unit to date, with potential for further scaling without efficiency degradation. 3.4 Spectroscopy characterizations 3.4.1 Infrared spectroscopy for catalysts Infrared (IR) spectroscopy has been extensively used since the 1960s to investigate surface-adsorbed species on solid catalysts, providing insights into reaction processes and mechanisms [256,257]. Domen started his research on IR spectroscopy at the Tokyo Institute of Technology in the early 1980s and co-worked with Takaharu Onishi. His early works primarily focused on studying the adsorption and desorption of intermediates on solid catalysts during CO hydrogenation (CO-H2) reaction. For instance, studies on the CO-H2 reaction over ZrO2 revealed that the selectivity for methanol and isobutene formation varied with temperature [258]. The addition of In2O3 to CeO2 improved the CO-H2 reaction activity and increased selectivity for ethene while suppressing alkene formation [259]. Fourier-transform IR (FT-IR) analysis of intermediate species during CO adsorption on partially reduced CeO2 showed the information of a formyl intermediate, with the formation of carbonate-like species being inhibited [260]. It was also confirmed that CO adsorption was influenced by the degree of dehydroxylation on the CeO2 surface [261]. The adsorption of nitrogen species on materials such as Al2O3, TiO2, and ZrO2 was also studied using IR spectroscopy at a liquid-N2 temperature. It was observed that hydrogen adsorption affected the adsorption behavior of dinitrogen species on an alumina-supported cobalt catalyst [262]. Additional studies on TiO2 and ZrO2 revealed that dinitrogen was adsorbed at strong sites, while dihydrogen was adsorbed at weaker sites [263,264]. Zeolites, with their unique porous structures and abundant active sites, are crucial for various catalytic reactions. Domen et al. [265] utilized FT-IR spectroscopy to investigate the interaction between small molecules and zeolites by probing nonpolar molecules. They were the first to demonstrate that dinitrogen species can serve as a probe for acidic sites of zeolites. Specifically, N2 species adsorbed onto Brönsted and Lewis acid sites of H-mordenite, producing detectable ν(NN) vibration. Further studies revealed that CO could also act as a probe for active sites in H-form zeolites because it exhibited distinct behaviors when interacting with Brönsted acid sites, Lewis acid sites, and acidic-OH sites [266]. Additionally, the adsorption of H2, O2, and rare gases (He, Ar, Kr, and Xe) at low temperatures was examined using transmission FT-IR spectroscopy, with band shifts correlated to the number of strong acid sites in the zeolites [267,268]. Building on the foundational studies, Domen et al. [269,270] advanced their research to explore intermediates and processes involved in various catalytic reactions on zeolite surfaces. For example, they investigated the dehydration of ethanol using time-resolved IR spectroscopy, as shown in Fig. 25 [269]. The absorption bands at 3500 and 3000−1300 cm−1 were attributed to the alcohol-OH and zeolite-OH, respectively, both of which were in a hydrogen-bonded state. After a 10-min reaction, the disappearance of the absorption band corresponding to hydrogen-bonded acidic OH groups indicated the desorption of ethanol and water molecules (Fig. 25(b)). Concurrently, the appearance of isolated acidic OH groups suggested the consumption of acidic protons on the zeolite. Considering the absence of water produced from ethanol dehydration, the consumption of acidic OH groups, and the presence of ethyl groups, the stable intermediate for ethanol dehydration on zeolites was confirmed as an ethoxy group. These ethoxy species remained stable and were not replaced even when exposed to isotopic d 6-ethanol (Fig. 25(c)). In contrast, molecularly adsorbed ethanol species were replaced and decomposed at higher temperatures into gaseous ethene and acidic OH groups. These findings confirmed that ethanol dehydration on zeolites proceeds through a stable covalent intermediate at the solid-gas interface, as the process shown in Fig. 25(c) [271]. 3.4.2 Sum-frequency generation spectroscopy During his time as a visiting scholar at Dr. Chuang's lab, Domen focused on surface photochemistry using a UV laser, a powerful tool for examining the electronic state excitation dynamics of adsorbed species [272]. Domen's research highlighted the characteristic electronic excitation effects, providing evidence of molecular selectivity in photo-desorption, which was linked to fragmentation and explosive desorption behavior observed at high surface coverages. His study employed an ultra-high chamber consisting of XPS, thermal desorption spectroscopy (TDS), and time-of-flight mass spectrometry (TOFMS). TDS and XPS were used to access surface coverage and the adsorption characteristics. Domen also investigated the photodissociation and desorption mechanisms of CH2I2 adsorbed on the surfaces of Al2O3 and Ag under electronic excitation [273]. His findings revealed that most excited molecules beneath the surface could not dissociate owing to repulsive interactions and collisions with neighboring molecules when the CH2I–I bond distance increased in the excited state. Inspired by the pioneering research of Professor Shen [274,275], Domen began researching infrared-visible sum-frequency generation (SFG) in surface and interface chemistry based on ultrashort vibrational spectroscopies in the 1990s. This technique, illustrated in Fig. 26 , involves irradiating a surface with simultaneous intense visible and infrared pulses. The emitted SFG light, which results from the sum of the wavenumber vectors of the pulses, increases sharply if the infrared pulse frequency resonates with surface vibrations. This sharp increase allows for the vibrational spectrum to be obtained by scanning the infrared frequency. The sensitivity and surface specificity of SFG make it an ideal tool for studying thin films. In 1991, Domen published his first study using SFG, focusing on the anisotropic orientation of Langmuir-Blodgett (LB) films of cadmium arachidate on fused silica [276]. He subsequently applied SFG spectroscopy combined with temperature-programmed desorption to investigate the variation of the MgO (001) surface during formic acid adsorption and thermal desorption [277]. Due to the insulating and nonmetallic properties of MgO (001), studying its surface with vibrational spectroscopies presented challenges. Domen demonstrated that SFG spectroscopy with high selectivity could detect molecular vibrations specific to adsorbed formic acid and its decomposition directly on the MgO (001) surface, offering valuable insights into controlling chemical reactions on MgO surfaces, particularly those involving surface defects. SFG spectroscopy offers ultra-short time resolution due to the picosecond timescale of the pulsed laser. Domen observed that exposure to near-infrared pulses induced a transient temperature jump at the surface (Fig. 26) [278]. Leveraging this phenomenon, he explored the decomposition of formate on the NiO(111) surface by identifying short-lived reactive intermediates using picosecond temperature jump (ps-T jump) techniques [279]. The research provided deep insights into the surface chemistry of NiO(111), particularly in understanding how reactive intermediates influence the decomposition reactions at the atomic level. Uncovering the vibrational relaxation of surface molecules is crucial for understanding how molecules interact with surfaces on a microscopic level, such as through chemisorption, diffusion, and desorption during chemical reactions. These insights help researchers assess the accuracy of theoretical models related to vibration relaxation and energy transfer at interfaces [280,281]. Time-resolved infrared spectroscopy is particularly effective for such analyses [282]. In this context, Domen et al. [283] conducted a series of studies focusing on the vibrational dynamics of hydroxyl groups on zeolites, specifically Y-type and mordenite. They measured the population lifetime using a pump-probe method, where the adsorbate was excited to a vibrational mode with a tuned intense IR laser pulse, and the recovery of the ground-state population was monitored with time-delayed probe pulses. The relaxation lifetimes of the OH (v = 1) groups of Y-type zeolites were observed to be 180 ± 12 and 63 ± 14 ps, corresponding to OH stretching bands at 3625 and 3540 cm–1, respectively. Additionally, the decay time of the transient hot band absorption at 3457 cm–1 (v = 2 ← 1) on the surface of OH groups of mordenite was confirmed by pumping the fundamental band at 3608 cm–1. The measured decay time was 154 ± 18 ps, consistent with the 161 ± 18 ps obtained from the bleaching experiment of the fundamental band. Subsequently, Domen et al. [284] conducted the tunable IR pump-probe experiments to investigate the vibrational relaxation rates (v = 1 ← 0) of the OH stretching mode of Brönsted acidic hydroxyl group in a mordenite-type zeolite interacting with molecular adsorbates such as He, Ar, Kr, and Xe. Based on the experimental results, they used a simple linear chain model to study the mechanism behind the improved relaxation rate. Further advancing their research, Domen et al. [285] examined the reaction dynamics of highly thermodynamic stable trans-2-butene adsorbed to acidic hydroxyl groups on the surface of ferrierite zeolite. Previous studies had identified species reacting with another molecule after proton transfer from zeolite at around 300 K using typical vibrational analyses, but short-lived monomolecular intermediates formed at the early stages of the reaction had not been directly observed. Domen et al. [285] were the first to obtain transient absorption spectra for the trans-2-butene/zeolite system by employing picosecond IR laser spectroscopy in the period immediately after exciting the OH (OD) stretching mode with an intensive IR pulse. This allowed them to study the lifetime of short-lived intermediate species and elucidate their forming mechanisms. Domen et al. [286] later expanded their research to study catalytic reactions on single-crystalline metal surfaces using IRAS and SFG spectroscopy. These techniques, unlike conventional electron spectroscopy and microscopy, can be conducted under ambient conditions, allowing for observations under in situ and Operando conditions. Typically, physisorbed π-bonded ethylene can only exist below 54 K under vacuum conditions. However, under vacuum, the adsorbed ethylene coordinated on Pt(111) through a di-σ-bond remained stable up to 250 K, after which it decomposed to ethylidyne above 250 K (Fig. 27 ) [287–289]. Subsequent studies utilizing ultrafast vibrational spectroscopy have validated this pioneering research by Domen et al. [178,290–292]. 3.4.3 Mechanism research Photocatalytic systems often include cocatalysts to facilitate surface reactions. Understanding the interfacial charge transfer between the photocatalyst and cocatalyst, as well as the surface potential of the cocatalyst, is critical for elucidating reaction mechanisms and improving the system efficiency. To monitor the potential of cocatalysts like Pt on a photocatalyst, Domen et al. [293,294] used CO as a probe molecule and gathered vibrational data through in situ attenuated total reflection surface-enhanced infrared absorption spectroscopy (ATR-SEIRAS, Fig. 28(a) ). In this approach, CO molecules adsorbed on the cocatalyst exhibit a frequency shift in the C–O stretching vibration, which reveals the potential at the adsorption site. This shift occurs due to electron transfer to the 2π* orbital of CO and/or an electrochemical Stark effect (Fig. 28(b)) [295]. Initially, this technique was applied to a n-type GaN substrate loaded with Pt particles, demonstrating that the CO peak shifts observed through ATR-SEIRAS were directly linked to potential variations caused by photoexcitation [293]. This study further uncovered that the Schottky barrier between GaN and Pt limited electron accumulation in Pt due to the competitive transfer of electrons and holes from GaN to Pt. Expanding on this model, the technique was applied to particulate photocatalysts, including Pt-loaded GaN:ZnO, TaON, and LaTiO2N particles under in situ conditions [294]. For Pt-loaded GaN:ZnO and TaON, the C–O stretching vibration of adsorbed CO shifted to a lower frequency under visible light irradiation, signaling electron accumulation on the Pt cocatalyst. In contrast, no frequency shift was detected on Pt-loaded LaTiO2N. These findings were strongly correlated with the photocatalytic H2 evolution activities of these materials. Further studies revealed that the poor charge transfer between LaTiO2N and Pt, leading to minimal photocatalytic H2 evolution, was attributed to a defective surface layer on LaTiO2N [118]. Removal of this defective surface layer significantly enhanced the photocatalytic activities of LaTiO2N. Effective separation of photogenerated charge carriers in photocatalysts is crucial, as it directly impacts their ability to transfer to cocatalysts, a process that competes with charge recombination. To study charge-carrier dynamics in photocatalysts, various transient optical spectroscopies, such as photoemission and absorption spectroscopies, have been developed. Among these, transient absorption spectroscopy stands out for its broad applicability across all relevant timescales for charge carriers. This technique, especially when using a pump-probe method, is sensitive to both radiative and non-radiative decay processes [297]. In a collaboration study between Domen and Yamakata [298], time-resolved infrared absorption spectroscopy (TR-IR) was developed to investigate charge-carrier dynamics in semiconductor materials. IR absorption was selected because the absorption coefficient for photogenerated electrons increases as the probe light wavelength extends from the visible to IR region. This is particularly important because free or shallowly trapped electrons, which are closely associated with photocatalytic processes, generate structureless broad absorption in the mid-IR region [299,300]. Furthermore, IR absorption is not affected by the visible light emission from charge recombination, making it a reliable method for studying these dynamics. In addition to the qualitative analyses, semi-quantitative analysis based on TR-IR is also possible. By comparing the absorption intensities of free or shallowly trapped electrons in photocatalysts with and without a cocatalyst, researchers can determine the proportion of electrons captured by the cocatalyst. TR-IR was first validated by studying the potential-dependent charge-recombination kinetics in n- and p-type GaN photoelectrodes, where the steady-state reaction efficiency was correlated with the number of electrons that survived in the millisecond range. Since photogenerated holes often produce absorption bands in the visible region, time-resolved absorption spectroscopy was extended to cover the visible to mid-IR regions (TR-vis/IR)) [296]. This range, from 400 nm to 10 µm, spans an energy level from 0.1 to 3.1 eV, enabling detailed analysis of energy states associated with charge-carrier trapping (Fig. 28(c)). Applying the TR-vis/IR method to Pt or/and CoO x -loaded LaTiO2N photocatalyst clarified the multiple roles of cocatalysts. For example, while Pt was found to extract electrons from LaTiO2N, this process took tens of microseconds due to deep-trapping effects. In contrast, CoO x rapidly captured holes within a few picoseconds and allowed long-lived electrons to survive, as CoO x could partially passivate surface defects and improve electronic properties. Analyses also unexpectedly revealed that high-loading amounts of both Pt and CoO x led to undesirable charge recombination. These findings promoted more careful selection of cocatalysts and their loading conditions in subsequent studies [88,105,123,173,224]. Although co-loading both Pt (HEC) and CoO x (OEC) on LaTiO2N was expected to facilitate both electron and hole transfer to reaction sites, TR-vis/IR analysis showed that when Pt and CoO x were deposited in close proximity, a new, unfavorable recombination process was induced, reducing the steady-state activity. To optimize the co-loading strategies, later studies confirmed that the loading amount of cocatalysts, particularly OEC, should be minimized, or the HEC and OEC should be spatially separated on different crystal facets [40,77,301,302]. Given the effectiveness of TR-vis/IR as a tool for analyzing the charge-carrier dynamics, this method has been applied to various photocatalysts, including SrTiO3, BaTaO2N, SrTaO2N, among others, and facilitating their optimization [71,88,91,105,124,152,162]. Since photocatalyst particles generally have rough surfaces with strong light scattering, transient diffuse reflectance spectroscopy (TDRS) was employed to detect transient absorption signals and investigate charge-carrier dynamics. To enhance the analytical power of TDRS, it was coupled with theoretical modeling and numerical simulation based on DFT and COMSOL Multiphysics. This combined approach has proven to be a powerful tool for uncovering the physical mechanisms behind charge-carrier dynamics and extracting critical parameters, such as doping density, which are often challenging to accurately measure using conventional methods [46,303–310]. This methodology was particularly effective when applied to cutting-edge photocatalysts, such as Y2Ti2O5S2 and SrTiO3:Al [46,92]. For instance, studies on Y2Ti2O5S2 revealed that factors including particle size, donor density, and trap density significantly influenced bimolecular recombination, trapping and de-trapping processes. This led to the introduction of optimized design strategies that balance particle size, doping density, and tail-trap states to achieve high quantum efficiency in water splitting [307]. Similarly, analyses on SrTiO3:Al showed that Al doping reduced the intrinsic n-type doping density, significantly prolonging bulk carrier lifetime and diffusion length [309]. Rapid electron extraction by a cocatalyst, exemplified by Rh, just before charge carriers decay, resulted in extraordinary quantum efficiency for water splitting. This comprehensive approach, which links material and electronic properties with carrier dynamics and photocatalytic activities, is expected to drive the design of novel photocatalysts for efficient solar-fuel production in the future. 4 International collaborations Artificial photosynthesis using photocatalysts and photoelectrodes represents a promising pathway toward achieving carbon neutrality, a challenging yet crucial goal for researchers worldwide. Recognizing the importance and broad applicability of this research area, Professor Domen has actively engaged in international collaborations. Between 2010 and 2015, Domen et al. [106,146,311–315] worked closely with Can Li from the Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics and Jae Sung Lee from the Ulsan National Institute of Science and Technology under the A3 Foresight Program supported by the Japan Society for the Promotion of Science. This collaboration has continued, advancing the development of novel photocatalysts and photoelectrodes for water splitting. Notable achievements include the development of the MgTa2O6–x N y /TaON heterostructure for hydrogen evolution, a composite photocatalyst used in Z-scheme water splitting with a recorded AQY of 6.8% at 420 nm at that time. Additionally, a tandem cell combining the NiOOH/FeOOH/BiVO4:Mo photoanode from Lee's group and the Pt/CdS/CuGa3Se5/ (Ag,Cu)GaSe2 photocathode from Domen's group achieved a remarkable STH of 0.67% over 2 h without degradation [315]. While the Domen team's primary focus has been on inorganic semiconductors including oxides, (oxy)nitrides, and (oxy)sulfides, they have also significantly contributed to the development of organic photocatalysts. Collaborations with Markus Antonietti from the Fritz-Haber-Institute of the Max-Planck-Society and Xinchen Wang from Fuzhou University led to the development of polymeric carbon nitride for photocatalytic water splitting [316–319]. This material, notable for its chemical and thermal stability, represents the first artificial conjugated polymer semiconductors for artificial photosynthesis. To understand the complex physical and chemical processes involved in photocatalysis, Domen has partnered with Ib Chorkendorff from the Technical University of Denmark to investigate the operational mechanisms of photocatalysts using silicon-based µ-reactors. Their research revealed the importance of suppressing backward reactions on cocatalysts with a Cr2O3 layer [320,321]. In a similar vein, collaboration with James Robert Durrant from Imperial College London focused on developing an operational model for SrTiO3:Rh and SrTiO3:La,Rh, by integrating in situ spectroelectrochemical measurements with density functional theory and photoelectron spectroscopy [322]. Throughout his research career, Professor Domen has collaborated extensively with researchers from China, many of whom have become outstanding independent scholars upon returning to their home country and continue to work with him. For instance, Fuxiang Zhang from the Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics has advanced (oxy)nitride photocatalysts for water splitting [107,108]. Recent collaborative work with Domen has utilized strong metal-support interactions to enhance photocatalytic performance, resulting in a suspended photocatalytic Z-scheme water-splitting system comprising TaON and BiVO4 with a benchmarking AQY of 16.9% at 420 nm at room temperature [107]. In collaboration with Yanbo Li from the University of Electronic Science and Technology of China, Domen et al. [323–325] have developed well-defined Ta3N5 photoanodes and yielded a half-cell STH of 4.07%. Li's group has also employed temperature/power-dependent and time-resolved photoluminescence spectroscopies to explore the electronic structures and carrier dynamics of photocatalysts like Y2Ti2O5S2 from Domen's group [326,327], providing valuable insights into design principles for efficient water-splitting photocatalysts. Professor Domen also extends his research to other photosynthetic processes, such as CO2 reduction and H2O2 generation. For instance, in a collaborative effort with Erwin Reisner at the University of Cambridge, they combined the SrTiO3:La,Rh|Au|BiVO4:Mo photocatalyst sheet with the phosphonated cobalt bis(terpyridine) molecular catalyst to achieve CO2 reduction to formate in aqueous solution. This system demonstrated a solar energy conversion efficiency of approximately 0.08% with a selectivity to formate of 97% [18]. Additionally, by utilizing faceted BiVO4 particles developed by Domen's group, Chiheng Chuat Zhejiang University applied advanced cocatalyst engineering to create an efficient and stable inorganic system for H2O2 photosynthesis [301]. 5 Conclusions and outlooks Professor Domen and his team have devoted considerable efforts to exploring effective photocatalytic systems for solar hydrogen production via water splitting. Their work has led to high levels of photocatalytic performance, continuously setting new benchmarks in the field. Such research laid the scientific foundations and design principles for highly efficient photocatalytic systems and also highlighted that meeting a substantial portion of humanity's energy needs will require breakthroughs in materials development, tightly integrated with advances in device design and engineering. The strategies typically employed by the Domen team to enhance photocatalytic performance are summarized in Table 4 . Enhancing η absorption: to enable the practical application of photocatalytic materials, improving η absorption is essential. In response to this challenge, Domen and his team have focused on developing novel photocatalysts, including oxides, (oxy)nitrides, and oxysulfides, that can harvest visible light while maintaining relatively good stability in aqueous solutions. These materials have shown promising photocatalytic activity for HER, OER, and overall water splitting. For metal oxides with valence bands composed of O 2p orbitals, achieving both H2 and O2 production requires a bandgap energy exceeding 3 eV, allowing the oxide to span the potentials necessary for proton reduction and water oxidation. By adjusting the valence band potential using p orbitals, specifically N 2p or S 2p orbitals, to form (oxy)nitrides and (oxy)sulfides, the Domen team has successfully narrowed the bandgap. Many of these materials can absorb light with wavelengths up to 600 nm or even longer. However, one of the major challenges in achieving overall water splitting with materials other than oxides, such as (oxy)nitrides and (oxy)sulfides, is self-photocorrosion, which leads to low stability during the photocatalytic reaction. To address this issue, surface loading with OECs may be necessary to suppress the oxidation of lattice nitrogen and sulfur ions, ensuring stable water oxidation to O2. Doping, by introducing foreign elements into host materials, is another effective strategy to shift the optical response towards the visible light region. However, dopants can also act as recombination centers for photoexcited carriers, reducing photocatalytic activity. Therefore, it is crucial to carefully control the choice of dopants, the doping concentration, and the method of doping to optimize performance. Solid solutions of isostructural semiconductors offer significant advantages, as these mixtures readily undergo orbital hybridization between different atoms and/or distortions of metal-oxygen octahedral or tetrahedral units, resulting in modifications to their band structures. The bandgaps and energy levels of these materials can be continuously adjusted by varying the contributions of wide- and narrow-bandgap semiconductors. This solid-solution approach has enabled precise control over the bandgaps and band-edge positions of semiconductors designed for single-photoexcitation water splitting. Enhancing η separation: Developing efficient photocatalysts requires optimizing light absorption without sacrificing charge separation. In this context, Domen and his team have implemented several strategies to enhance photocatalytic performance, including defect engineering, cocatalyst engineering, and facet control. A major challenge in achieving high photocatalytic efficiency is the significant charge recombination that occurs at defect sites. The addition of a salt mixture in the material synthesis process, such as NaCl/KCl, has been shown to improve crystallinity, modify grain boundary structures, and reduce defect formation. This molten salt synthesis method has been successfully applied to produce photocatalysts with high crystallinity and fewer defects. The photocatalytic performance of particulate semiconductors is also highly dependent on their crystal planes, as surface reactions are sensitive to the atomic structures and physicochemical properties of the exposed surfaces. Spatial charge separation has been observed in several single crystals across different exposed facets. Creating nanoscale and microscale junctions with built-in electric fields offers a potential approach to further enhance charge separation and improve overall performance. Enhancing η reaction: The kinetics of the OER and HER play a critical role in determining photocatalytic performance. The thermodynamically uphill water-splitting reaction, characterized by high activation energy or overpotential, often results in low activity. This is especially true for the OER, where the multistep proton-coupled electron transfer process is kinetically slow. To address these limitations, cocatalysts are commonly employed to efficiently extract photogenerated charge carriers and drive redox reactions. The activity of OECs and HECs depends on several factors, including cocatalyst loading, particle size, structure, composition, and the interface between the cocatalyst and semiconductor. Domen's work demonstrated that precise control and optimization of these variables are essential for enhancing performance. Back reactions involving molecular oxygen, such as the oxygen reduction reaction and water formation from the evolved hydrogen and oxygen, are common challenges during simultaneous stoichiometric H2 and O2 generation in overall water splitting. These reactions must be suppressed. A surface modification strategy, which involves covering noble metal cocatalysts with an amorphous (oxy)-hydroxide layer, has been shown to effectively inhibit back reactions on the cocatalyst without affecting hydrogen evolution. By combining these strategies, more efficient cocatalyst materials for overall water splitting have been developed. Mechanism investigation: Domen's contributions have been pivotal in deepening the understanding of photocatalytic systems. Through the use of advanced spectroscopic techniques, such as ATR-SEIRAS and TR-IR, Domen and his collaborators have gained critical insights into the intrinsic carrier properties of semiconductors and the interfacial charge transfer processes between photocatalysts and surface decorations. Their research has clarified the roles of surface potentials and charge-carrier dynamics in enhancing photocatalytic activity. It also highlights the importance of optimizing cocatalyst loading and spatial arrangement, which significantly affects charge separation and recombination, thereby improving photocatalytic performance. Additionally, the integration of theoretical modeling with experimental data has been a central component of his approach, facilitating the extraction of key parameters and the development of more efficient photocatalysts for solar hydrogen production. Device design for future practical applications: The device design has shifted over the past decade, with solar fuel production technologies advancing toward integrated, compact, and panel-structured systems that are better suited for widespread use [254]. Professor Domen has consistently focused on the practical application of his research, leading his team in the development of cost-effective water-splitting systems and versatile technologies for fabricating simple yet efficient photo(electro)chemical devices. His innovative methods include particle-transfer techniques, rolling-press methods, and screen-printing approaches for preparing photoelectrodes and photocatalyst sheets from photocatalyst particles. These technologies combine the advantages of both PEC and PC systems, offering the high efficiency of PEC systems along with the simplicity, scalability, and low-cost potential of photocatalysts. Future development: Technoeconomic analysis suggested that the target for solar energy conversion efficiency in particulate photocatalytic water splitting for solar H2 production should be set at 5%–10% in the next phase. Attaining this efficiency range is crucial for making solar H2 production economically viable at a large scale, enabling the technology to compete with other renewable energy sources and address the growing demand for sustainable energy solutions. To achieve this critical STH threshold, future research and development should focus on exploring and optimizing photocatalyst materials, enhancing reaction systems, and scaling up production processes. It has been suggested that photocatalytic evaluation can begin if the material has a bandgap within the range of 1.5–2.5 eV [328]. Otherwise, a photon collection strategy must be employed to effectively harvest visible light without compromising charge separation efficiency. Bandgap modulation and tuning of band-edge positions can be achieved through doping and the formation of solid solutions.
