However, the doping level and the ratio of the two isostructural materials must be precisely controlled to prevent the formation of deep trapping and recombination sites for photoexcited carriers. Despite significant challenges, such as the presence of numerous defects and the competitive self-oxidation of (oxy)nitrides and (oxy)sulfides, it remains essential to prioritize the development of these visible-light-driven photocatalysts. This focus is necessary because UV light accounts for only a small portion of solar radiation. Achieving the target STH of 5%–10% is unattainable with most photocatalysts that primarily absorb UV light, such as many oxides, even with a QE of 100% and without considering entropic losses. To reach the STH target of 10%, the absorption edge of photocatalyst must extend beyond 520 nm, which corresponds to a bandgap smaller than 2.4 eV [329]. Constructing a Z-scheme system is an alternative approach for efficient sunlight capture. Current Z-scheme designs often focus on effective interparticle electron transfer but may overlook mismatches in the band structures of the HEP and the OEP. For instance, in a typical Z-scheme setup using SrTiO3:La,Rh and BiVO4, both with a bandgap of 2.4 eV, the maximum theoretical STH efficiency is approximately 5% [255]. This value is consistent whether the materials are used in a powder suspension form or a photocatalytic sheet configuration, similar to that achieved with side-by-side PEC cell configurations. With particulate panel technology, improved solar utilization and higher water-splitting efficiency could be realized by designing a new Z-scheme system where the photocatalysts are stacked. In a dual-stacked absorber configuration, photons with energy lower than the bandgap of the top absorber are transmitted to the bottom absorber. For such a dual-stacked system, the maximum theoretical STH efficiency is 22.8%, achievable with bottom and top photoabsorber bandgaps of 1.23 and 1.84 eV, respectively [255]. To develop materials with high crystallinity and low defect density, several synthesis challenges must be addressed. First, ensuring that metal ions in the precursor materials are in the correct chemical valence states is vital for forming a well-ordered crystal structure. Second, maintaining stoichiometric balance in the final product is essential, as deviations can introduce defects and non-uniformities, reducing crystallinity and increasing defect density. Finally, optimizing synthesis conditions-such as temperature, atmosphere, and reaction time—helps minimize defects and promote crystal growth. Careful control over these factors is key to produce materials that exhibit both high crystallinity and low defect density, which are critical for enhancing the performance of photocatalytic and other functional materials. Apart from the strategies developed by the Domen team, such as defect engineering and facet control, several other approaches have been explored to enhance charge separation and migration. These include reducing photocatalyst particle size or creating core-shell structures to shorten charge carrier migration distances, forming junctions between metals and semiconductors, between semiconductors with different bandgaps, and between electrolytes and semiconductors. Additionally, introducing specific functional groups onto the surface has been shown to improve performance. These methods have been detailed in previous reviews [196,330,331]. In plants, specialized catalytic sites are dedicated to both CO2 reduction and water oxidation, effectively preventing the recombination of photoexcited carriers and accelerating redox reactions. Studying these natural systems is crucial for understanding the fundamental aspects of photosynthesis and for developing processes for artificial photosynthesis and commodity manufacturing. To achieve efficient photosynthesis, electrons must participate in multielectron charge transfer processes to initiate reduction reactions or be transferred to electron-accepting entities. Most photocatalysts need cocatalysts to drive these reactions effectively, as semiconductor-based reactions typically proceed slowly on their own. Therefore, it may be necessary to load both OECs and HECs on a single particle. In such configurations, synergistic interactions and the spatial separation of OECs and HECs are critical. Facet engineering, which directs OECs and HECs to their respective sites, is a sophisticated approach to managing the spatial separation of cocatalysts and could lead to the development of more effective materials for overall water splitting. Recently, hybrid systems, such as enzymes and molecular complexes inspired by nature, have been explored as alternatives to inorganic nanoparticles for use as cocatalysts in semiconductor-based photocatalytic reactions. These hybrid cocatalysts are expected to provide more active sites for catalysis compared to nanoparticulate cocatalysts [332,333]. Despite the extensive development of electrochemical catalysts for HER and OER, only a limited number of cocatalysts, such as RuO x , NiO x , and RhCrO x , have demonstrated the ability to effectively decompose water into hydrogen and oxygen. Integrating these catalytic technologies from electrocatalysis into photocatalytic systems remains challenging. This is because loading electrochemical catalysts onto photocatalysts is limited by preparation methods. Without careful adjustment, the energetics at the photocatalyst/electrochemical catalyst interfaces often result in severe charge recombination. However, recent research has shown that depositing Al2O3 onto Rh cocatalysts in GaN-ZnO systems via atomic layer deposition (ALD) can significantly inhibit reverse reactions, thereby improving photocatalytic water splitting activity by over an order of magnitude [334]. Although ALD is traditionally used for depositing protective oxide layers with precise atomic-level control in solar cells and (photo)electrode films, its application to photocatalytic powder systems has been challenging. This work demonstrates the feasibility of applying various effective strategies used to optimize solar cells and (photo)electrodes such as regulating the interfacial microenvironment and the electron spin-orbital [335–339], to improve the photocatalytic systems. Furthermore, the use of 1D/2D and nanoscale multicomponent materials is becoming increasingly prevalent, as nanostructured photocatalysts offer enhanced performance due to shortened carrier diffusion paths and precise material combinations at the nanoscale. Solar energy systems generally garner strong support from technologists, regulators, politicians, and environmental groups. Achieving a sustainable solution for global energy demands will necessitate not only enhanced energy efficiency and innovative approaches to existing carbon-based fuels but also a significant expansion of carbon-neutral energy sources. Professor Domen's research spans multiple fields, including photocatalysis engineering, semiconductor physics, (photo)electrochemistry, and spectroscopy. His work integrates laboratory studies, simulations, observations and characterizations to develop versatile materials and strategies for photocatalytic research. While his research is centered on water splitting, the materials and techniques he has developed have potential applications beyond this, including CO2 reduction, N2 fixation, photo-reforming, and organic transformations. However, these broader applications have been less explored with the materials and methods developed by his team. Most importantly, Professor Domen's contributions extend well beyond the laboratory. His efforts focus on translating fundamental research into practical applications, bridging the gap between scientific discovery and real-world implementation. His vision includes harnessing solar energy to tackle global energy challenges and contribute to a more sustainable and resilient future. Through his pioneering work, he has inspired a new generation of researchers to push the boundaries of photocatalysis and solar energy utilization. As Professor Domen celebrates his 70th birthday, we celebrate his ongoing innovative research in photocatalytic water splitting. We hope that his vision of producing green hydrogen through this technology will soon come to fruition. We also wish for sustained harmony among research, engineering, and manufacturing efforts, leading to sunlight becoming a primary, cost-effective contributor to a sustainable global energy system. Zhenhua Pan (Associate Professor at Department of Applied Chemistry, Graduation School of Engineering, University of Hyogo, Japan) earned his Ph.D. from the University of Tokyo under the supervision of Prof. Kazunari Domen in 2016. In April 2020, he became an assistant professor in the Katayama Lab at Chuo University. In April 2024, he started his own lab at the University of Hyogo as an associate professor. His research focuses on the development of wide-spectrum-responsive photocatalysts for artificial photosynthesis, the investigation of photochemical processes in photocatalytic reactions, and the creation of scalable photocatalyst panels. Qian Wang (Associate Professor at Nagoya University, Japan) obtained her PhD in 2014 from the University of Tokyo under the supervision of Professor Kazunari Domen, followed by postdoctoral research at the same institution. In 2018, she was awarded the Marie Sklodowska-Curie Research Fellowship and joined the Reisner Group at the University of Cambridge. Since joining Nagoya University as an Associate Professor in May 2021, she has established her research group focused on developing innovative materials, strategies, and technologies for solar energy storage through artificial photosynthesis, with the goal of producing renewable fuels.

coredata.dc:description: ABSTRACT Professor Kazunari Domen at the Shinshu University and the University of Tokyo has pioneered materials and techniques for solar-driven water splitting using photocatalysts, a promising technology for contributing to the construction of a sustainable and carbon-neutral society. In this paper, we summarize his groundbreaking contributions to photocatalytic water splitting and, more broadly, photocatalytic research. We highlight various novel functional photocatalytic materials, including oxides, (oxy)nitrides, and oxysulfides, along with innovative techniques such as cocatalyst engineering and Z-scheme system construction developed by the Domen Group. His team has also pioneered readily accessible and cost-effective photo(electro)chemical device fabrication methods, such as the particle-transfer method and thin-film-transfer method. Furthermore, their research has made significant contributions to understanding the (photo)catalytic mechanisms using advanced characterization techniques. Together with his research team, Professor Domen has set many milestones in the field of photocatalytic overall water splitting, notably demonstrating the first scalable and stable 100 m2 solar H2 production system using only water and sunlight. His work has revealed the potential for practical solar H2 production from water and sunlight, and highlighted the application of fundamental principles, combined with chemical and materials science tools, to design effective photocatalytic systems. Through this review, we focus on his research and the foundational design principles that can inspire the development of efficient photocatalytic systems for water splitting and solar fuel production. By building on his contributions, we anticipate a significant impact on addressing major global energy challenges.
